column2: From the advocates of the constitutional amendments to the leaders of Tammany Hall there is a general agreement among all classes of people interested in the Municipal Government of New-York that the most urgent need of the City is the opportunity of governing itself.

There are those who look with alarm upon the publication of newspapers in the avowed interest of the dangerous classes. The recent establishment of two newspapers--one of which is intended to be the organ of plumbers, while the other is devoted to the interests of agents--has created much uneasiness in the community.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. The Senate Finance Committee met to-day, and, in accordance with previous assignment, took up the House bill providing for the repeal of the Specie Resumption act.

Detective Thompson, of the Central Office, to whom has been intrusted the case of black-mail in which the Princess Souvaroff, of Russia, figures so prominently, up to last night had not succeeded in obtaining a definite clue to the guilty person. Vice-President Wheeler being absent, the Senate was called to order by Secretary GORHAM. MR. FERRY CHOSEN PRESIDENT PRO TEM. Mr. ANTHONY, of Rhode Island, submitted a resolution, "That in the absence of the Vice-President, Hon. T.W. Ferry be and he is hereby chosen President of the Senate pro tem."

The marriage of Mr. Horace Russel, Assistant District Attorney, and Miss Josephine Hilton, youngest daughter of ex-Judge Henry Hilton, was solemnized last eight at the residence of the bride's Parents, No. 7 West Thirty-fourth-street.
The contest over the will of the late Commodore Vanderbilt was resumed yesterday morning before Surrogate Calvin.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. The contest over the nomination of a Collector for the port of Boston was terminated to-day by the nomination of Alanson W. Beard to succeed W.A. Simmons, whose term is about to expire.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 26.--The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Lehigh Navigation Company held to-day proved a rather exciting affair, as there was considerable open dissatisfaction expressed at the statements made in thereport of the President.

Mr. BAYARD'S bill "to authorize bondholders and other creditors of railroad corporations to elact Receivers in suits in equity pending in the courts of the United States," appears to be an inadequate remedy for a flagrant wrong.

ALBANY, Feb. 26. The House signalized its return to business by a night session of unusual length, most of the time being taken up in debate upon Mr. Hepburn's United States Loan Commissioners' bill. It was attacked with much force by Mr. Gilbert, assisted by Mr. Graham, of Orange; Mr. Bergen, of Kings,....

The Children's annual Carnival and Ball in the Academy of Music last evening, in aid of the North-western Dispensary, was a gratifying success, both artistically and in point of numbers. By 8 o'clock every seat in the house was filled and a great portion of the standing room was occupied by fashionably-dressed spectators.

The limited express this morning brought to this city a large number of horsemen from New-York and the New-England States to attend the auction sale of thoroughbred horses from Col. David McDaniel's Stony Brook stud farm at Princeton.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26.--The House Committee on Pacific Railroads held an adjourned meeting this morning in relation to the subject of equal advantages and facilities and equal mileage rates on the Union Pacific Railroad and its branches.

FORTRESS MONROE, Feb. 26. An order has just been received by Gen. George W. Getty, commanding the Artillery School, United States Army, relieving the officers who have been under instructions for the past two years, and assigning others in their places, to take effect on the 1st of May. Register Little has granted the application of Lucius Lyon, formerly of the Finkle Lyon Sewingmachine Company for his discharge from bankruptcy. He owed $95,000, and had no assets.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. The President is preparing a Message on the Silver bill which he will read to the next meeting of the Cabinet.

Soon after the House had assembled this morning, an effort was made to call up the PhillipsMarsh contested election case. Phillips, it will be remembered, is the seated member from one of the Essex districts. The Committee of Election reported, as they did in the Cooper case, in favor of unseating him.

An important decision in regard to the law of civil orders of arrest was rendered by Judge Lawrence, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, in the suit of the Bowery National Bank against Gen. Abram Duryee.

The seventh annual meeting of the American Fish Culturists' Association was commenced at the rooms of the Board of Directors of the Fulton Market Fishmongers' Association yesterday morning, Mr. Robert B. Roosevelt, the President, in the chair. Mr. Barnet Phillips, the Secretary, read the minutes of the last annual meeting, after which an obituary notice of Mr. B.F. Bowes, a member of the ...

The Ladies' Reception at the Union League Club last evening was a brilliant success, and the large attendance must, no doubt, in a great measure be attributed to the propitious weather, resembling far more the still serenity of a night in early May than the storming season of the equinox.

ALBANY, Feb. 27.--The Joint Committee on Canals of the two houses gave a hearing this afternoon to the friends of the bill introduced by Senator St. John to make the canals free without taxing the people, by granting the right to run a narrow gauge railroad on the tow-path for the towage of boats, the grantees agreeing to Day the State $900,000 a year to keep the canals in repair.

There are frequent gatherings of journalists and literary men at the house of Victor Hugo, in the Rue de Clichy, and one never leaves there without feeling that the evening had been profitably spent. There is no more interesting conversationalist in the world than Victor Hugo.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 27.--The following amendment was agreed upon by the House Committee on Banking and Currency to the Treasury-note bill heretofore reported from that committee:

ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 27.--The Agence Russe says the conditions of peace published in London are inaccurate. Russia has never demanded the expulsion of the Mussulman inhabitants of Bulgaria. She has only demanded the recall of the Turkish officials and troops. Russia does not hand over a portion of Bosnia to Servia.
The depositions of James A. Reilly and Augustus T.R. Martin, taken in the Erie Railway litigations, were filed in the County Clerk's office yesterday.

According to the politicians of the school of Gen. BUTLER, the working people of the United States are specially interested in having a cheap, plentiful, irredeemable paper currency, issued by the Government.

LONDON, Feb. 27.--There is a marked contrast between the opinions of the situation at Vienna expressed by various correspondents. The Manchester Guardian's special correspondent says: "War with Russia is not believed possible, and the opinion prevails that mobilization, if decreed, will be for the purpose of occupying Bosnia and Herzegovina, as Russia desires."

Questions connected with the reformatory institutions of the State engaged a large share of the attention of both branches of the Legislature to-day. In the House a long discussion was caused by the placing before the members, for final passage, of a bill prohibiting the making of hats and shoes in the State Prison. The discussion took a wide range, and the whole question of the propriety and advisability ...

LONDON, Feb. 28.--The Standard, in its leading article, says: "All that is really implied by the selection of Lord Napier of Magdala as Commander-in-Chief, and Sir Garnet Wolseley as his Chief of Staff, is that the terms of peace, if unmodified, cannot be sanctioned by England. We have been brought face to face with war by the arrogant and aggressive conduct of Russia."

Shephard, of Newport, R.I., held its second session yesterday at the Army Building, in Houston-street. There were present Col. William F. Barry, Second Artillery; Col. Henry J. WASHINGTON, Feb. 27.--The bill reported by Representative Reagan from the Committee on Commerce, for the regulation of inter-State commerce and to prevent unjust discrimination as to freights, charges, and facilities by railroads and other common carriers, is accompanied by an elaborate report in favor of its passage. It says, among other things, "When we consider the magnitude of the commerce ...

The 14 seamen of the American ship Levi G. Burgess who are charged with mutinous conduct and insubordination on the high seas on Jan. 17 and 18, on a voyage from Liverpool to Tybee, were again marched to court yesterday from Ludlow-Street Jail, and arraigned before United States Commissioner Shields for examination.
The Montgomery Advertiser says that ninetenths of the land in Alabama is valued at less than $10 per acre.

The objections that are made to the proposed changes in the Navigation laws of this country come chiefly from two quarters, namely, from those who are interested in the building of iron and wooden ships, and from those who have sailing vessels or steamers engaged in the coasting trade.

The Customs officials yesterday seized 1,000 smuggled Manila cigars on the ship Chapman, from Calcutta. Mr. A.P. Burbank gave a series of humorous and dramatic readings at Steinway Ball last night, before a large audience.

Mr. HOAR, of Massachusetts, presented the remonstrance of persons residing at Cape Cod, Mass., against the passage of the Sargent bill to organize a coast guard and life-saving service, and urging the passage of the bill introduced in the House on the same subject.

BERLIN, Feb. 27.--The National Zeitung cordially welcomes Mr. Bayard Taylor's appointment as United States Minister to Germany as one conferring honor on Germany and America alike, and calculated to strengthen the already strong ties between the two countries. "President Hayes," says the National Zeitung, "Deserves Germany's sincere thanks."

Several of the Western States are wrestling with the school-book problem. In some of the older States, the question of supplying the public schools with text-books is surrounded with many vexations and difficulties.

HARRISBURG, Feb. 27.--Representative Donnelly, of Westmoreland, introduced into the House this morning a bill prohibiting, under penalty of not less than $200 nor more than $500 fine, any railroad or other transportation company from granting a free pass or passes at a discount to any person except to an officer or employe of such company issuing the same.

The Surrogate's Court-room was jammed with men and boys all day yesterday, during the hearing of the contest over the will of the late Commodore Vanderbilt. The order granted on Dec. 15, 1877, for the proponent to show cause why the original allegation of the contestant should not be amended, was brought up by Mr. Scott Lord at the opening of the case in the morning.

The Thirteenth Regiment will have a fulldress drill, promenade concert, and hop, at its armory, Flatbush-avenue and Hanson-place, to-morrow evening.

A large number of ladies and gentlemen attended the meeting of the American Geographical Society at Chickering Hall last evening for the purpose of listening to the annual address of ChiefJustice Charles P. Daly. Several prominent gentlemen occupied seats on the stage, including William Cullen Bryant, Peter Cooper, Judge Brady, Judge Curtis, Marshall O. Roberts, Rev. Dr. Hitchcock, Frederick De Peyster, Alvan S. Southworth, and Col. C.C. Long.

LONDON, Feb. 27.--Lord Napier of Magdala, Governor and Commander-in-Chief of Gibraltar, has arrived here from that place, and has had a long conference with the Duke of Cambridge. The afternoon papers announce very prominently that it has been decided to employ Lord Napier of Magdala as Commanderin-Chief of any expeditionary force that may be sent out in case of war, with Major-Gen. Sir Garnet Wolseley as Chief of Staff.

The report submitted to the House last Monday by Mr. WILLIS, of Kentucky, shows the true character of the Chinaman and renders it impossible for any honest patriot to venture to defend the yellow heathen.

"Lohengrin" was repeated at the Academy of Music, yesterday evening, with the same distribution of characters noted on the occasion of the first performance of the opera under the present regime.

Mr. WALSH, of Maryland, moved to take from the Speaker's table and pass the Senate bill amending the act providing for the publication of a new edition of the Revised Statutes. He explained that the bill simply made the new edition prima facie evidence in courts instead of conclusive evidence.

A meeting of the creditors of Kate Claxton, the actress, has been called by Register Fitch, to be held on March 29 to prove debts and choose an Assignee in bankruptcy.

The following is the full text of the President's veto Message:

The President has vindicated his consistency and his integrity, if not his courage, in the veto of the Silver bill. He has taken the only course which could save him from the responsibility and disgrace of participating, even impliedly, in the bad faith which this measure involves.

Let us give Gov. HAMPTON his due. With all his faults, he has striven with tolerable consistency, since his accession to office, to fulfill pledges which go far toward atoning for the doubtfulness of his title. Unlike the Governor of Louisiana, he has not stood idly by while promises made in behalf of his State have been shamefully violated.

ALBANY, Feb. 28.--The Committee on Cities held a long session this afternoon, and among the bills discussed ware several relating to New-York. Mr. John Strahan and Commissioner of Accounts Mooney appeared to speak upon the Financial bill, the bill to enlarge the powers of the Board of Apportionment, and the Bonded Indebtedness bill. Some verbal alterations were made in the latter, and it will probably be reported unanimously to-morrow.

LONDON, March 1.--The Vienna, correspondent Of the Times confirms the report that reassuring communications have been received from St. Petersburg. The negotiations have taken a better turn. The rumors of a large concentration of Russians on the Transyivanian frontier prove unfounded.

"Tommy" Lynch, a well-known character in the palmy days of the late "Jim" Fisk, Jr., and "Prince Erie," was committed to the Bloomingdale Insane Asylum yesterday. One day last Summer, while he was driving along Seventh-avenue, his carriage ran over a pile of stones upon a part of the thoroughfare which was undergoing repairs, and "Tommy" was thrown to the ground.

LONDON, Feb. 28.--A special to the Standard from Vienna says negotiations are proceeding between Russia and Servia, the object of which is to allow Russia to occupy Belgrade if a conflict with Austria should become inevitable.
ST. PETERSBURG, Feb. 23.--The Golos calls for the occupation of the Dardanelles by Russia. The Gazette de St. Petersbourg considers immediate war with England preferable to concessions.

The Revue Militaire de V Etranger gives some details which indicate the immense development which the well-known workshops of Herr Krupp at Essen have attained. The number of workmen employed at the present time in the establishment amounts to 8,500. The area of the ground inclosed by the wall which surrounds the factory is 400 hectures, 75 of which are covered by buildings.

Mary Ann Shute, the oldest unmarried lady in Elizabeth, died yesterday at the advanced age of 88. Miss Shute's father was an officer in the Revolution.

Mrs. Wilhelmina Boller, of No. 421 Thirdavenue, applied to Justice Smith Wednesday afternoon, in the Fifty-seventh-Street Police Court, for a warrant for her husband, whom she alleged was guilty of bigamy. The request was granted, and yesterday Officer Kellard, of the Court Squad, accompanied by Mrs. Boller, went to the cigar factory in Lafayette-place, where the accused works, and executed the warrant.

Much sympathy is being manifested among the Jews of this City in behalf of the sufferings which are known to prevail among their race in Turkey and other portions of the East, consequent upon the Russo-Turkish war. Not only from Bulgaria and other parts of the country which are directly affected by the war, but also from Palestine, have reports of destitution and suffering reached the Jews of this couutry, accompanied by appeals for aid.

The building was owned and occupied by Bernard Coy, and valued at $900; insured in the Westchester for $200.

--In England the Winter comes hard upon the professional tramp. But it is not his habit to take thought for the morrow, and, moreover, experience tells him that he can somehow tide through the cold. Wet he has got well accustomed to; and severe snow-storms and prolonged frosts are become the exceptions rather than the rule.

Magic is the name which has been given to all wonderful effects produced in some mysterious way. The Grand Jury will take up the case of Ann Lehmann, better known as the notorious Mme. Restell, to-day.

HOT SPRINGS, March 12. The liberal donation of $500 from the Chicago Board of Trade has swollen the cash contributions for the relief of the sufferers by the recent conflagration here to something over $2,000. Much has already been done for the relief of the most pressing needs, but a generous public should be informed that much still remains to be done, and that their efforts and contributions should not cease.

ALBANY, March 12. In the case of the People against the New-Amsterdam Savings Bank, of New-York, Jutice Westbrook has granted an order permitting the Receiver to sell the office furniture of the bank.

PHILADELPHIA, March 12. The annual meeting of the stockholders of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company was held here to-day, and was, perhaps, the most important gathering which has ever taken place in the history of the organization. The meeting which was very turbulent, hissing and other demonstrations of disapprobation being frequent was called for 10 o'clock, in the Musical Fund Hall, and there were nearly 3,000 people present.

VIENNA, March 12. At a joint sitting of the sub-committees of the Hungarian Delegation to-day, a motion to grant the credit of 60,000,000 florins, asked for by Count Andrassy, was unanimously adopted.

HARTFORD, March 12. The trial of William Allen for the murder of Welles Shipman, night watchman in the Connecticut State Prison, at Wetherfield, on the night of Sept. 1, 1877, was begun in the Superior Court in this city to-day, Judges Dwight W. Pardee and Elisha Carpenter, of the Supreme Court, on the bench. The prosecution is conducted by State's Attorney Hamersley, and Samuel F. Jones is Counsel for the accused.

The greater part of the morning session in the Vanderbilt will case yesterday was taken up by a discussion of counsel as to the introduction as evidence of declarations made by William H. Vanderbilt. Surrogate Calvin said that he would ,reserve his decision until he had deliberated upon the matter. Mr. Benjamin Wood was called to the witness' chair by Mr. Scott Lord, who endeavored to...

Surrogate Calvin yesterday admitted to probate the will of the late Ann Drake Seaman, widow of John F. Seaman, formerly of this City. The will contains 27 bequests, and disposes of property amounting to nearly $1,000,000. The Executors of the will are William C. Wetmore, Richard H. Bowree, William B. Isham, and John Cartree.

LONDON, March 12. The Mark Lane Express, in its review of the British Corn trade for the past week says: "Spring sowing has been carried on vigorously during the week, and, the land being in excellent condition, a large breadth of Spring Corn has been sown. The Autumn-sown Wheat-plant preserves its healthy appearance. Pastures promise an early and abundant Hay crop. English Wheat has been marketed in small quantities and unsatisfactory condition.

The opponents of the bill to repeal the law of last year forbidding the sale of pools on elections and on horse-races have at last commenced to move. The Society for the Prevention of Crime have taken the matter in hand, and will at once institute measures to give voice to the popular sentiment in favor of the law as it stands.

The calendar of the Special Sessions Court was enlivened yesterday with a case of more than ordinary interest, involving, probably, one of the most persistent instances of mendicancy on record. The prisoners were John J. Wilson and his wife Julia, of No. 21 West Thirteenth-street, whose household has long been known as the "Wilson family of mendicanis." They were prosecuted by Mr. W.H....

WASHINGTON, March 12. The Senate Finance committee this morning agreed to consider the House bill for a repeal of the Specie Resumption act at the next regular meeting on the 19th inst. The subject was not discussed to-day, the session being wholly devoted to private relief bills and executive business.

If Mr. HUNTINGTON exercised freely the sagacity with which he is credited, he would not allow Mr. JAY GOULD to drag the Central Pacific Railroad into unreasoning antagonism to Senator THURMAN'S Sinking Fund bill. Mr. GOULD'S position is clear. The Union Pacific in his hands is a speculation rather than a property.

Special Treasury Agent Brackett received private information recently that Mme. Rallings, a fashionable milliner and dress-maker, doing business at No. 1,153 Broadway, who was about to return from Europe on the Adriatic, intended to smuggle a large quantity of valuable foods, partly on orders for her customers and partly for sale in her shop. The Adriatic arrived on Monday afternoon.

The reproduction in a daily journal of the pretended letter of LENTULUS to the Roman Senate, in which the person of JESUS is described and his miracles narrated, shows how faith in a forged document may be kept alive, after it has been exposed in its true character a hundred times, and although its spuriousness is transparent to all well-educated persons.

Our latest dispatches from Berlin are to the effect that the Reichstag had passed the third reading of the Chancellor's Substitute bill. This brief announcement may seem of little, consequence, but in truth it records the progress of a measure of the greatest importance to the German Empire.

The calendar of the Court of Special Sessions yesterday included the first case of violation of the Excise law ever tried before the court. The complainant was Henry Quale, a tramp, and the prisoner was Timothy Kenny, the keeper of a fourth-class boarding-house at No. 60 Cherry-street, the resort of...

The advocates of a change in the present bankruptcy laws have frequently used as an argument the alleged fact that dishonest bankrupts make a practice of inserting in their schedules of liabilities spurious names of creditors, with large amounts opposite, in order to make as bad a showing as possible...

LONDON, March 12. In the House of Commons this afternoon Sir Stafford Northcote, Chancellor of the Exchequer, in answer to an inquiry by Sir Henry Wilmot, (Conservative,) member for South Derbyshire; said that the Government had not heard that the Russians were intrenching lines, across the Peninsula of Gallipoli.

Numerous complaints have lately reached Police Head-quarters to the effect that a bogus silver mining company were selling worthless shares of stock under the name of the Navada Silver Mining Company, Clark Co., Managers, offices No. 1,260 Broadway. The manner of doing business was to advertise in the rural districts by means of circulars and the local papers that the company had bought...

CONCORD, March 12. Election day has been a chilly, uncomfortable one about here, with a slight rain in the afternoon. Gov. Prescott and the various members of the State committees and many politicians returned to the city this afternoon to get the returns. The Republican head-quarters have been crowded with visitors since noon, all...

BOSTON, March 12. The American Powder Mills, at South Acton, Mass., exploded at 9:05 o'clock this a morning, causing much consternation and alarm. Two mills are wrecked, together with considerable machinery. The loss of life is confined to two hired men, Lowell Foster and Mr. Turpener, (or Turpenty,) both of whom leave relatives dependent upon them for support. Several other employes were stunned by the concussion.

Mr. SOUTHARD AND THE TRIUMVIRATE. Mr. SOUTHARD, of Ohio, rising to a personal explanation, said that the joint resolution introduced by him in relation to three Presidents was introduced by request. The idea of having more than one Executive head was not so chimerical as the press had been representing it, but had had many advocates in this country and examples in ancient history.

In the Senate, the bill to prohibit member becoming sureties for contractors with the Government was reported favorably. The bill authorizing the issuing of an American register to the steamer purchased by J.G. Bennett for a polar expedition was passed. A bill authorizing a review of the case of ex-Surgeon General Hammond was passed. The claim of Benjamin Holliday was referred...

About 150 tenants of Trinity Church, whose leases will expire on the 1st of May next, met last evening at No. 242 Spring-street "for the purpose of taking measures toward securing a reduction of rents to suit the times." Mr. Edwin Wainwright was called to the chair. After stating the object of the meeting, the Chairman introduced Mr. George M. Chapman, who made a long address explaining the...

The trial of Insurance Superintendent Smyth was resumed this morning before the Senate, all the members being present, except Senators Ecclesine, Morrissey, and Payne. There was full attendance of spectators, including several ladies. The Senate adopted a resolution fixing the hours for the trial from 10 A.M. till 2 P.M., and from 7 till 10 P.M., until otherwise ordered.

The trial of the singular suit brought by Charles Devlin, the contractor, against George M. Van Nort, formerly Commissioner of Public Works, was begun before Judge Van Verst and a Jury in Part II., of the Supreme Court, yesterday. Mr. Devlin in his complaint says that, between Jan. 1, 1872, and Jan. 1, 1875, he lent Mr. Van Nort $30,000, and that the latter repaid $20,000 of the...

Secretary Sherman has appointed a committee, composed of General Appraiser Meredith and Special Agents Brush and Hurd, to carefully investigate this subject. All the allegations will be referred to these gentlemen, and they will visit the principal cities from which the complaints come and make a full inquiry and report.

WASHINGTON, March 12. The Senate Committee on Finance was in session for a short time to-day, but transacted no business of importance. It was agreed that the bill which provides for the repeal of the Resumption act should be considered next Tuesday.

Mayor Ely has accepted an invitation to review the procession in honor of St. Patrick on next Monday. Seventy-seven permits for carrying pistols have been granted by Superintendent Walling up to yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 12. In the House to-day, general debate was continued on the Consular and Diplomatic Appropriation bill. Mr. Hale made a speech in which he contrasted the theory and practice of the Democrats on the subject of economy in the expenditures of the Government. He referred to the numerous bills introduced for the payment of Southern...

An adjourned meeting of the Board of Directors of the National Rifle Association was held yesterday afternoon, Judge N.P. Stanton, the President, in the chair. A communication was received from a printing firm offering the sum of $50 for the best design of a "score-blank" suitable for a rec-...

LONG BRANCH, Tuesday, March 12, 1878. For the past 36 hours a north-east gale of unusual severity has been breaking on the coast. As yet no marine disasters have been reported. The Life-saving Service men fear trouble along the shore to-night, and the patrols between Stations Nos. 1 and 9 will be doubled. The telegraph wires are all down, and there is but little communication below Wreck Pond.

To-day, in the Senate, the communication of the Secretary of the Interior in reference to a resolution relating to timber depredations in Montana was presented by the presiding officer. Senator Matthews tried to have the paper read and placed in the official Record, but was defeated by objections from Senator Sargent. The substance of the communication, which will be again called up to-morrow, is as follows:

ALBANY, March 12. The session of the Assembly to-day was "for debate only," or very nearly that, for nearly all of it was consumed in debate upon the proposed consitutional amendments. The first of these was one proposing a reduction of salaries of memebers of Assembly from $1,500, at which they now stand, to $750. Each year since the time when this compensation was established in place of the...

The fire which broke out at 1:30 yesterday morning in the oil and paint warehouse of F.O. Pierce Co., No. 174 Fulton-street, was not extinguished until nearly 3 o'clock. The origin of the fire has not been ascertained, but it is believed to have originated in the paint store on the first floor. The building was entirely gutted, the flames having extended...

HARRISBURG, March 12, The Riot Investigating Committee was in session again to-day. A number of witnesses were examined, among whom were Mayor Patterson, Sheriff Jennings, Senator Herr, ex-Senator Mumma, and Attorney-General Lear. The testimony of the Mayor related exclusively to the riots in this city. He detailed the circumstances attending the various stages of the disorders; the sympathy which the public at first manifested for the strikers; the increasing numbers and boldness of...

The President and Vice-President of the New-York Life Insurance Company made their tardy appearance on the witness stand to-day and contradicted the report that either or both of them had stated that the examination of their company by the Insurance Department cost $100,000. The committee which organized at a meeting held at No. 85 South-street on Wednesday evening last, to make arrangements for a union regatta of small yachts to be held in New-York Bay some time during the coming Summer, met lats evening at the Village Hotel, corner of Hudson and Bank streets. There were present ex-Commodore Joseph Noble, exCommodore A.L. Kerymeyer, Mr. J.D....

The Spring election in New-Hampshire yesterday was, in some regards, of unusual interest. It was the last election to be held at this time of the year, and the irregular parties, particularly the Prohibitionists, thought it an opportune occasion to make a push for an increase of power in the Legislature and for a demonstration of their strength on the general ticket.

In 1868, before Tweed came to the heyday of his popularity, his two daughters insured his life in the Knickerbocker Life Insurance Company for $10,000, by what is known as an endowment policy. This policy had 10 years to run, the time expiring on April 1 of the present year. On the latter date the daughters were to receive the amount of the policy in case their father was still alive.

Hon. Charles L. Wilson, of Chicago, died on the 9th inst. at San Antonio. Texas, Mr. Wilson was for many years editor and proprietor of the Chicago Evening Journal, his connection with that paper having begun as far back as 1845. He was born in Fairfield County, Conn. Oct. 10, 1818; was the son of John Quintard and Maris Lush Wilson, and was descended from John Wilson, who was a...

ABOUT A ROCKLAND COUNTY CORONER. The inquest to discover the cause of the death of John Burns, the employe of the United States Marshal's office in this City whose body was found on Monday morning in the slip of the ferry-boat that runs between Nyack and Tarrytown, was closed in the former village yesterday morning.

The section of our City lying near to the Central Park, between Sixty-sixth and Sixty-seventh streets and Madison-avenue, is giving evidence of coming improvements. Mr. Ira E. Doying, the well known builder, has nearly completed three rows of brown-stone four-storied houses which will contain all the modern appliances for comfort and labor-saving...

The schedules were filed in the Court of Common Pleas yesterday in the matter of the assignment of Franklin Walter, Robert C. Thomas; Samuel T. Donaldson, and Howard Walter, firm of Walter, Donaldson Co., to Andrew W.Kent. The assigners were coal-dealers, having offices at No. 111...

James C. Bayles, editor of the Iron Age, lectured last evening before the New-York Academy of Useful Arts, in the Cooper Institute, on "Sanitary Engineering." The lecture was devoted to a discus sion of the evils of imperfect sewerage and the methods for their removal. The great prevalence of sewer-gas poisoning the lecturer considered attributable to popular ignorance of the importance of perfect drainage and properly ventilated sewers.

WASHINGTON, March 12. For some days a sensational story has been whispered about the hotels that Jere Black has been secluded at a hotel, with several prominent Democrats, preparing papers preliminary to beginning a movement intended to test the legality of President Hayes' title, or to begin some kind of legal proceedings against the "visiting statesmen," either at New-Orleans or Washington.

In answer to numerous requests, we have agreed to issue an early day a supplement to THE TIMES, printed in Spanish, devoted exclusively to New-York interests, and designed to convey to merchants in the principal cities of Mexico and...
The argument in the case of "The Exiles" was yesterday adjourned until to-day, in consequence of the engagements of ex-Judge Dittenhoefer, one of the counsel for Mr. Duff, of the Broadway Theatre.

The Producers Protective Union of Bradford and Tarport, Penn., and Olean, N.Y., have sent S. W. Blakely to this City to ask the co-operation of the various commercial bodies in an endeavor to keep open the Genesee Valley Canal. Mr. Blakeley has drawn up a statement of facts which will be presented to the Board of Trade and Transportation for consideration at their meeting to-day.

The trial of the suit to annul the marriage of Georgiana Morison and Joseph Lopez was continued in the Special Term of the Supreme Court, before Judge Van Brunt, yesterday. The first witness was Henry G. Schutz, a detective, of No. 373 Broomestreet. He described the "shadowing" of Lopez through various liquor stores, and houses of ill-repute, and the latter's meeting with Sarah Lillis, near Reservoir-square.

Notwithstanding the inclemency of the weather, there was a large audience at the Brooklyn Academy of Music last evening to listen to Rev. Dr. Storrs' second lecture on "The Ottoman and Muscovite." It was devoted to a monograph upon the rise and development of imperial Russia in the first instance and to a discussion of the long struggle between the...

SHERMAN, Wyoming Territory, March 12. On Thursday last, about midnight, a storm of snow and wind set in, covering the entire country from Green River, Wyoming, to North Platte, Nebraska, a distance of 550 miles, which proved by far the severest storm since the construction of the Union Pacific Railroad. During the latter part of last December Rev. Octavius Brooks Frothingham's Life of Gerrit Smith was published by Messrs. George P. Putnam's Sons, and on Friday last that firm announced that the biography had been withdrawn from publication. PARIS, March 12.--La Republique Francaise states that Lord Derby, British Foreign Secretary, told Count Schouvaloff, the Russian Ambassador at London, that England would not attend the congress unless the entire treaty of San Stefano was submitted thereto, and that Count Schouvaloff, after consulting with Prince Gortschakoff, replied that Russia would consent, the congress itself deciding what pionts ought to be examined.

The Board of Aldermen yesterday took final action upon the question of erecting an armory on Washington-square, as proposed by the Tammany members of the Committee on County Affairs. Alderman Waehner spoke in favor of the adoption of the report of the committee on the subject, a synopsis of which has appeared in THE TIMES.

An amiable Methodist minister, who recently took tea on Sunday evening at the white House, has published in a denominational newspaper a touching and beautiful account of the way in which the Presidential family, together with a few friends, subsequently sang hymns.

It has been known to many persons in this City for a long time that United States prisoners sent to Ludlow-Street Jail to await trial, or to the Kings County Penitentiary to serve our sentences, were permitted to leave those insititutions temporarily, and to visit friends either in this City or...

HARRISBURG, Penn., March 13.--The Senate to-day passed finally a bill creating a Banking Department, to be under the charge of a Bank Examiner, whose duty it shall be to annually examine into the soundness and stability of the incorporated banks of the State, and when any such institutions are not on a sound basis to compel them to cease doing business.

POUGHKEEPSIE, March 13.--Another disclosure was made to-day in the social affairs of Mrs. Corn Pearl Husted. It will be remembered that some time ago this women procured a divorce from her husband, Charles H. Husted, but it was set aside on the ground that he had not been served with the necessary papers.

The Fortifications Appropriation bill was reported in the Senate. A bill to establish a Mint at New-Orleans was introduced. A bill was reported from the Committee on Claims in favor of paying the Methodist Southern Book Concern $150,000 for damage to property at Nashville during the war.
The Organizing Committee of the City Democracy (Brunswick Hotel wing of the anti-Tammany Domocrats) met last evening at No. 8 Unionsquare, Mr. Georgo W. McLean in the chair.
Once during the early part of the war of the rebellion, a Senator from Oregon made a speech in favor of a somewhat doubtful bill, then before the Senate of the United States.

The Chancellor of New-Jersey has terminated the legal proceedings brought before him by ordering the property known as the Long Branch Race-course to be sold for the benefit of mortgages. The Sheriff of Monmouth County has advertised that he will sell the property at 2 o'clock on the afternoon of April 5, at the Court-house in the town of Freehold.
The Treasury will to-morrow receive 10,000 silver dollars from the Philadelphia Mint.

The proposal to further reduce the salary of the public school teachers in this City is an excellent one. That those idle people who never carried a hod full of bricks or laid a water-main in their lives should receive more pay than is earned by the honest working man, is an outrage.

WASHINGTON, March 13.--The bill introduced by Senator Gordon to-day to promote the deposit of savings and the refunding of the national debt, provides for the issue of a new series of United States coupon bonds in denominations of $20, $50, $100, $500, and $1,000, bearing 3 per cent. interest, payable semi annually, the bonds being payable at the option of the United States, either at the...
WASHINGTON, March 13.--The House today passed the Consular and Diplomatic Appropriation bill, substantially as it was reported by the order of the Committee on Appropriations.

The suit brought by Messrs. Tompkins Hill, of Boston, to restrain James A. Duff, of the Broadway Theatre, from producing or giving performances of the play of "The Exiles," was, before Judge Donohue in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, on the return to the order directing the defendant to show cause why the preliminary injunction should not be continued.

ALBANY, March 13.--Two-thirds of the legislative session have passed, and not until this morning has a single debate taken place on party issues, or a single vote been given on party lines since the organization of the House. There has been nothing in the daily proceedings of the Assembly for weeks or months past which would make it appear to an observer that there were two opposing parties in it.
There seems to be considerable life left in the grand old party after all. Secretary McCrary used to write poetry for an Iowa paper. Now he is a man of martial spirit.

BALTIMORE, March 13.--The Sun this morning gives the following: "One of the most remarkable instances of alleged barratry that has been brought to light here in a good many years was developed yesterday, a British brigantine and her whole cargo of coffee being represented to have been 'appropriated' by a passenger, in collusion with her Captain and crew, and brought here to be sold.

The House yesterday passed the bill making appropriations for the consular and diplomatic service, with a few unimportant amendments. WASHINGTON, March 13.--The usual dull routine in the Senate was relived, to-day, by a sharp political speech from Senator Blaine, and an interesting discussion in regard to the Military Academy Appropriation bill.

A year ago, just after Rutherford B. Hayes, the Republican candidate for the Presidency had been installed in the White House, two old campaigners, one of them a rebel General of cavalry, whose name is familiar in all parts of the country, and the other a citizen of New-York, who had won distinction while commanding a brigade in the Union Army, met in the bar-room of a leading hotel.

Mr. De Cordova lectured at Chickering Hall last evening on "Courtship and Marriage." A memorial meeting was held last evening in memory of the late Hon. Benjamin F. Wade at Shiloh Church, No. 140 Sixth-avenue.

PARIS, March 13.--Louis Andrieux, Radical Republican, member of the Chamber of Deputies from Lyons, challenged Paul de Cassagnac, Bonapartist, Deputy for Condom, well known as the editor of the Pays, to fight a duel in consequence of an article in the Pays.
Congressman Killinger has addressed the following letter to the editor of the Harrisburg (Penn.) Telegraph:

Jehial Read Co., wholesale dealers in hats and straw goods, at No. 596 Broadway, suspended yesterday, and issued a circular to that effect to their creditors, at the same, time informing them that they had placed all their assets in the hands of Mr. H.H. Stotesbury as voluntary Trustee.

Mr. George W. Kidd, a wealthy distiller, residing at No. 16 East Forty-seventh-street, in close proximity to the Windsor Hotel, on Thursday last was detained down town, and as he did not arrive at home at the usual hour, his wife become alarmed, and, sending for a coach, drove to her husband's place of business, No. 21 Whitehall-street.

LONDON, March 13.--A special dispatch from Berlin to the Morning Post says that Prince Bismarck will not go to his Lauenburg estate for the benefit of his health as was stated in a Berlin special in yesterday's Standard, and that the German Government will not, issue invitations to the congress until all difficulties about the subjects to be considered thereat are removed.

The Board of Trade and Transportation held a stated meeting yesterday afternoon. Mr. A.B. Miller reported that the committee of which he is a member had a hearing before the legislative Railroad Committee. A seemingly favorable impression was made, and a further hearing was set down for today at 3 o'clock at the instance of Mr. Depew.

WASHINGTON, March 13.--While the House was considering the Consular and Diplomatic bill to-day, in Committee of the Whole, Beverly Douglas, Representative of the First Virginia District, succeeded in creating an excitement both novel and disgraceful. Mr. Douglas is in the habit of indulging too freely in the flowing bowl.

The air is full of conflicting rumors, canards of every size and color fly about the Stock Exchange and the boulevards, until even the most cautious speculators are taken in and done for, as the political tension is so great that it is impossible to foresee what the next 24 hours may bring forth.

The indignation of stockholders of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company comes too late to be commendable. It would have been more efficacious as well as more seemly had it been manifested before the policy whose results they denounce had attained the proportions which render these results inevitable.

The Police Athletic Club gave a complimentary exhibition at Gilmore's Garden yesterday afternoon, for the purpose of finishing the programme advertised on the 8th of January last. The first event was a 220-yard hurdle race, in which there were three contestants. John Grassick, E. Scanlon, and J.J. Farley. Grassick won the race in 0:33 , Scanlon being second and Farley third.

WASHINGTON, March 14.--In the Senate to-day most of the session was occupied by Stanley Matthews, who made a carefully prepared speech in favor of the Pacific Railroad Funding bill, which was reported from the Railroad Committee on Tuesday last, and which has since been strongly urged by Jay Gould, Abe Van Vechten, and the large and powerful lobby controlled by them.

The failure of Baldwin Flagg, hat manufacturers at Yonkers, who have an agency at No. 48 Greene-street, is announced. The firm, which was one of the largest manufactures in the country, became embarrassed last Fall, but obtained an extension from their creditors in interest-bearing notes at 6, 9, 12, and 15 months. Mr. Gustave Koch, aged 40, proprietor to a lager beer saloon, at. No. 326 East Eighth-street, died at his residence yesterday morning under singular circumstances. At a late houron Saturday night, George Grob, Christian Vonderlind, and John Bromberger, all of West Hoboken, and friends of Koch, called upon him at his saloon and were well received.

The fifth reherasal of Mr. Thomas' "extra series occured at Steinway Hall yesterday afternoon. The programme included a new fantasia by Rheinberger, Liszt's plano concerto No. 1, in E flat, and Beethoven's Fifth Symphony. The fantasia is a good specimen of bright and muscular writing, not conspicuous for very felicitous ideas, but resting on clear and shapely themes, and substantialin treatment, without being overloaded with detail.

NEW-CASTLE, Del., March 22. In the jailyard here this morning, Samuel Chambers and George Collins, convicted of having committed an outrage on a white woman named Kate Smith in August last, were hanged. About 250 persons witnessed the execution, which was conducted in an orderly manner, and was unattended by any exciting circumstances. The men passed a tranquil night, and breakfasted this morning about 8 o'clock.

LONDON, March 23. Daniel O'Leary, of Chicago, the American representative, has won the first prize in the great international pedestrian contest, at Agricultural Hall, in this city. Kobbe Ball, dry goods auctioneers, at Nos. 87 and 80 Leonard-street, have become financially embarrassed, and will probably make an assignment to-day. The firm had excellent credit, and were the successors of William A. Kobbe Co., in 1872, their capital being estimated at $175,000.

Cardinal McCloskey expects to leave Rome on his way homeward on Monday."

The local election in Jersey City leaves the boards politically as they were last year. The Board of Police and Fire Commissioners will stand five Democrats to one Republican; the Board of Works six Democrats, and the Aldermen and the Board of Education eight Democrats to four Republicans each.

As announced in yesterday's TIMES, Launcelot Cormack Fogarty, of No. 330 West Forty-secondstreet, murdered his wife Margaret and then destroyed himself by cutting his throat. Subsequent developments make it all but certain that Fogarty also intended to murder his three children, William, aged 15; James J., aged 13, and Ellen, aged 10, and that he was prevented from doing so by the merest accident only.

CHICAGO, April 19. George McElwain, formerly engaged in the jewelry business in this city, filed a voluntary petition in bankruptcy this morning. His liabilities are all unsecured, and amount to $33,000. Warren G. Bent, a contractor doing business in this city, went into bankruptcy.

WASHINGTON, April 19. In the House to-day the Democrats, by a vote of 129 to 113, succeeding in postponing the final adjournment resolution until May 15. Mr. Wood's motion to refer the resolution to the Committee on Ways and Means was withdrawn and It will lie on the table until the date indicated.

Mr. Alfred G. Benson, an old merchant of this City, died on Wednesday night at his residence at Bay Shore, Long Island. He had been a victim of paralysis for several years. Mr. Benson was born in Maine in 1804. He came to this City in his youth, and when only 22 years of age became associated with a Mr. Buck in the shipping business.

Hon. Severn D. Moulton, the father of Mr. Francis D. Moulton, and one of the oldest and most prominent citizens of the Nineteenth Ward, died of pneumonia yesterday at his residence, No. 580 Lexington-avenue. The disease grew out of a cold contracted about a month ago while he was visiting his brother's residence.

The name of the lady who a few weeks since dropped her back hair on the sidewalk of a street in Clinton, Illinois, has now been ascertained. The hair in question was of a bright red color, and few persons would have imagined that it was dangerous when unconnected with its owner.

Mr. George W. Blunt, Secretary of the Board of Pilot Commissioners, died at 6:30 P.M. yesterday, after a lingering illness, in the seventyseventh year of his age. In January last, in alighting from a Broadway stage, he lost his balance and fell heavily upon the pavement, receiving a severe confusion of the right frontal region. He was taken home stunned, bleeding, but not wholly insensible.

NEW-ORLEANS, April 20. This was the first day of the Louisiana Jockey Club Spring meeting. The first event was a hurdle race, mile heats, over four hurdles, for a purse of $250, $50 to go to the second horse. The starters were Redding, Risk, Dalgaisian, and Jim Hinton. The race was won by Dalgaisian, with Risk second and Jim Hinton third.

The first concert of the New-York Stock Exchange Glee Club was given in Chickering Hall last evening. It was a strictly private affair that is to say, no tickets were sold, but enough were given out by the members of the Exchange to fill the hall three times ever. The expenses were defrayed by passing around the hat.

POUGHKEEPSIE, April 20 A few months ago Mrs. Eliza Peek came to this city from Schenectady and engaged board with Mr. Joseph Horsefall, at No. 62 Cannon-street. She was the widow of Harmanious Peek, who died a few years ago at Schenectady, leaving her a very large fortune. Mr. Peek was a Protestant. Last Fall, Robert Palmer, a lawyer in this city, drew up Mrs. Peek's will.

The banks of the Hudson, like every other beautiful region on the face of the earth, seem to have been made for the pleasure of the walker. At almost any point of its course from Sandy Hook to the Adirondacks are delightful routes, offering the charms of artistic cultivation, the homlier comforts of farm-life, or the more impressive elements of wild and romantic scenery.

The railroad has permitted all the world to travel, and the consequence is that modern travelers see nothing of the picturesque lands which they invade. People who have traversed the American Continent in a Pullman palace car will not be slow to admit that they see but little before they reach the Sierras, and then nothing at all, for the snow-sheds hide everything.

The butchers yesterday made very attractive displays and did a brisk business. A peculiar feature of the markets during the entire season has been in comparision with these of past years, the cheapness of all Lenten supplies, such as fish, eggs and the like.

STROUDSBURG, Penn., April 20. This portion of Pennsylvania is greatly excited over the case of Edward Melvin, charged with wife-murder, and whose trial is to take place in this place at the May term of court. Edward Melvin had lived with his family for some years in the upper part of this county, near the Luzerne County line. The vilage nearest where they lived was Gauldsboro, on the Delware and Lackawanna Railroad, two miles distant.
The Veteran Association of the Seventy-first Regiment will hold its annual meeting at Delmonico's next Monday evening at 7:30 o'clock. After the meeting the aunual banquet of the corps will be held.

Nothing is more lamentable than the frequency with which the political opinions of public men are misrepresented by a partisan and unpriucipled press. Cyrille Dion won the championship title, gold medal and first prize in the national tournament at fifteen-ball pool, at the Union-Square Billiard Rooms last night, by defeating Gotthiel Wahlstrom, the Swede, and making a clean score for himself against all competitors.

Judge Choate, the newly-appointed Judge of the United States District Court, sat yesterday for the first time to hear motions, and disposed of a large amount of bankruptcy business. To-morrow he will take up the calendar of causes in Admiralty.

The magnificent ocean steamer, the Australasian, was bound for England, on her homeward voyage from Melbourne. She carried Her Majesty's mails and ninety-eight first-class passengers. The skies were cloudless; the sea was smooth as glass. Never did vessel start under happier auspices. No sound of sickness was to be heard anywhere; and when dinner-time came there was not a single appetite wanting.

The body of an unknown man is at the Morgue in Long Island City awaiting identification. He was struck by an improvement train on Nottavenue, near the Court-house, and instantly killed. He was apparently about 50 years of age, 5 feet 10 inches in height, and dressed in a black and blue sack coat, black striped pantaloons, blue flannel shirt, black necktie, and a pair of heavy boots.

The eve of Easter Sunday is, perhaps more full of pleasure for many Christians than the Day of Resurrection. It commends itself to Episcopalians and Roman Catholics especially, by a certain feeling of relief resulting from the knowledge that it is the close of the period during which they subject themselves to rules which, however willingly obeyed, are none the less irksome.
The rowing season has began on the Harlem River, and the squeak of the oar is heard throughout the annexed district.

Philadelphia sends an unusual number of pictures to the National Academy this year not less than 15 Philadelphians are entered as exhibitors. The ladies of the Mount Vernon Aid Society, who have for several years been exerting themselves to collect an endowment fund to maintain forever the homestead of Washington, are anticipating a substantial benefit from a performance of the pantomime of "The Sleeping Beauty," which is to be presented at the Academy of Music on the evenings of Thursday and Friday next.

NORWICH, Conn., April 20. Representatives of the Yale Navy met gentlemen from New-London and Norwich to-day, and determined upon the site of the quarters for the Yale crew while in final preparation for the Yale-Harvard contest on the Thames River, June 28. Harvard has also chosen its position, and thus every important factor in the preparations for the aquatic struggle has been determined.

FRANKLIN, La., April 22. Jackson Edwards, Westley Turner, and Alexander Brown, all colored men, suffered the extreme penalty of the law at 11:10 o'clock this morning. The procession, led by a priest and the Sheriff, moved from the jail a few minutes before 11 o'clock and ascended the scaffold. The three condemned men then knelt with the priest who offered up a prayer to which the condemned listened attentively.

The experience of the City of Fall River for the last few years is but a type of that of the whole country. It was substantially a product of the "flush times." In 1860 it was a quiet manufacturing town of less than 15,000 inhabitants, given to steady habits and methodical but unpretentious modes of business.

A lecture on "The Perils of The Time" was delivered before a large audience by Rev. Dr.John Hall last evening in the Brick Presbyterian Church, on Fifth-avenue. Dr.Hall said that one of the perils that threaten the country grows out of a defective sense of responsibility among those who, possessing intelligence and wealth, fail to take part in the methods by which our officials are put in nomination.

"The Bells," a three-act play founded upon a well-kown novel written by Erckmann-Chatrian, and called "The Polish Jew," was acted at the FifthAvenue Theatre Monday evening. Hughes, the pedestrian, continued his weary tramp all day yesterday and last night, at Central Park Garden, in his effort to surpass O'Leary's great walk at Agricultural Hall, London, of 520 miles in 139 hours and some minutes. He came on the track at 3h. 11m. 40s. yesterday morning to begin his one hundred and seventh mile, after sleeping five hours--the first sleep he had had since Saturday night.

WASHINGTON, April 27. Most of the session to-day in the House of Representatives was in Committee of the Whole. The first sitting, Mr. Potter, of New-York, in the chair, was on the Indian Appropriation bill. CLEVELAND, April 27. Politics for the next Congressional canvass in Hamilton County are already assuming a lively tone. The first and second districts of the State are located in Cincinnati, and to estimate the State one should begin there. The first district has been strongly Democratic. Milton Sayler, the present incumbent, will be a candidate for re-election, with a fair chance of getting the nomination.

LONDON, April 29. Mr. Gathorne Hardy, Secretary for India, presiding at a banquet in Bradford to-night, said the Government took its stand upon public faith and honesty, and upon the declaration of 1871, that one party to an arrangement could not withdraw from it without the consent of the rest.

Sherman. These gentlemen had spent the day in witnessing the batteries exercising at target practice.

LONDON, April 29. Gen. Sir Alfred Hastings Horsford has been selected as commander of the Second Army Corps. Yesterday was looked forward to in Constantinople with considerable apprehension of the consequences which might result if the Russian troops attempted to enter the city under the pretext of hearing mass in the Greek churches, but the day passed quietly. Only a small number of Russians came in on Saturday night, most of whom spent the night in cafes chantant. Only about 50 of them attended church.

The Manchester Guardian's Vienna, correspondent telegraphs to that journal as follows : "The Hamburg-American Packet Company's steam-ship Cimbria, which has been chartered by the Russian Government, has taken a contingent of 40 officers and 500 seamen and started to cruise on the Chinese and Japanese coasts."

WASHINGTON, April 30. The Committee on Ways and Means to-day, by a vote of 8 to 3, agreed to report affirmatively a bill to suspend the law creating the sinking fund. Those who voted against suspension were Messrs. Garfield, Burchard, and Banks. The Senate Finance Committee, in considering a similar proposition, decided against suspension.

The troubles between ex-Congressman FOX and Senator Hogan, which culminated on Monday night in the three-cornered fight between Fox, Hogan, and Dr. William L. Shine, in the Stevens House, began as far back as 1874. Hogan was then Fox's candidate for Congressman against Edwin R. Meade, the Tammany nominee, and was defeated because Fox was unpopular.

CONSTANTINOPLE, April 30.?An affray has occurred between Russian and Turkish soldiers, near Daud Pasha Barracks, about two miles beyond the fortifications. Eighty men were wounded on both sides. The Seraskierate has consequently prohibited Russian soldiers from crossing the line of demarkation.

The little State of Rhode Island has taken time by the forelock, called her Legislature together, and got a bankrupt act of her own, so that embarrassed debtors within her limits may be discharged from their liabilities on surrendering all their property, and creditors can obtain all there is to be applied for the satisfaction of their obligations.

MANCHESTER, May 1. At a meeting of the Committee of the Spinners' and Manufacturers' Association yesterday a communication from the operatives was received, offering to submit the subject of the reduction of wages to arbitration, but the committee decided to refuse arbitration. READING, May 2. A telegraphic dispatch from San Francisco announces the death of Mr. W.S. O'Brien, of the firm of Flood O'Brien, at San Rafael yesterday afternoon, after a lingering illness lasting several months. His death will in no way interfere with the business of the firm.

OMAHA, May 2. General crop reports from various parts of the State are flattering to the highest degree. There is an increased acreage, an early season, and sufficient rain has fallen to give promise of the most abundant yield over known in the State. Only one destructive storm has occurred, and this barely touched the North Platte counties bordering on the Missouri River.

Morrill, Maxey, and Burnside, held a long session last evening, and agreed upon the terms of a bill to appropriate the net proceeds realized from the sales of public lands, after June 30, to educational purposes.

The Union League Club held its regular monthly meeting and reception last night, and the throngs of members who attended gave indication that business of some importance was to be considered. Local annals are evidently the stones for building the complete edifice of American history. It is, therefore, impossible to exaggerate their importance, or offer too much encouragement to their production. The only condition to exact is, that every stone shall be a solid fact, well squared.

WASHINGTON, May 9. Capt. Eads is here, and intends asking Congress for modification of the Jetty act. He claims that upward of 80 per cent. of work required to complete the jetties has been done, and less than 20 per cent. of contract price has been paid by the Government.
Eighteen creditors, whose claims aggregate $65,000, have filed a petition in bankruptcy against the firm of Keiler, Wormser Kingsbury, wholesale clothiers, at Broadway and Grand-street.

The twenty-fifth annual meeting of the American Congregational Union was held yesterday afternoon in Room No. 68 Bible House. Mr. A.S. Barnes, of Brooklyn, presided, and Prof. N.A. Calkins acted as Secretary. Prayer was offered by Rev. David B. Coe, after which the Treasurer's report was read.

POTTSVILLE, May 9. Two fatal accidents occurred in collieries near this place to-day. The first was at the Gate View Colliery, on the outskirts of Pottsville, and was of a very unusual character. It was shortly before 7 o'clock, and the men were going to work, being lowered down the slope, which is very steep, in mine cars.

LONDON, May 9. The master cottonspinners at Ashton-under-Lyne, Staley Bridge, Dukinfield, and Mossley have resolved to reduce the wages of operatives 5 per cent. after the 25th of the present month. The operatives, who accepted a reduction last November, will probably strike now.

CLEVELAND, May 9. The marriage of Senator Don Cameron to Miss Lizzie Sherman, the longtalked-of event among the society gossips, has been celebrated. The wedding was one of the most elaborate and costly affairs which Cleveland people have ever witnessed.

LONDON, May 9. The new British steam-ship Chicago, of 1,390 tons gross measurement, from West Hartlepool for Boston, with a cargo of soft coal, is ashore off Harwich. She has been abandoned and is full of water. A heavy sea is running at the scene of the disaster. The crew have been saved.

In 1844 Christopher Neville Bagot, a youth of great spirit, and a member of a family which has lived in Ireland upward of 700 years, resolved to push his way in the world, and left home for Australia. His father aided him with a gift of $5,000, and his subsequent success as a flockmaster and grazier was remarkable. In 1860 Mr. Bagot returned to his native land a very wealthy man.

An Italian bandit, named Pasquale Francolino, chief of the famous "Francolino" band, which recently committed so many outrages in the County of Potenza, Province of Basilicati, Italy, is hourly expected at Castle Garden, where detectives are on the watch for his arrival.

The anniversary exercises of the Deaf and Dumb Asylum were held at the Broadway Tabernacle yesterday afternoon. About 100 children were assembled on the platform, and the body of the church was crowded with invited guests.

PHILADELPHIA, Penn., May 9. The National Convention continued its deliberations until 2:30 this morning. Mr. GOODE, of Virginia, Chairman of the Committee on Education and Labor, reported a joint resolution providing for the enforcement of the Eight-hour law. WASHINGTON, May 13. The resolution to investigate the late Presidential election was introduced in the House to-day by Mr. Potter, of New-York. It is preceded by a preamble reciting the memorial of the Maryland Legislature, and provides for the appointment of a special committee of 11 to investigate alleged frauds in the conduct of the Presidential election in the States of Florida and Louisiana.

Major-Gen. Thomas Spencer Dakin, commanding the Second Division, National Guard, Brooklyn, died suddenly, at his residence, No. 376 Pearl-street, at 5:45 o'clock yesterday morning. His death was wholly unexpected 15 minutes before its occurrence.

NEWBURG, May 13. On the 5th and 6th inst. heavy rains fell throughout the fruit-growing districts of Ulster County. The peach, apple, cherry, and other fruit trees were then in blossom. The growers say the rain washed the "pollen" out of the peach blossoms, thereby damaging the coming crop to a considerable extent. On Saturday night last the dew was frozen on the plum, apple, and pear trees.

LEXINGTON, May 13. The attendance at the races to-day was very large. The ladies grand, and public stands were filled to their utmost capacity, and every available spot from which the race could be seen was crowded. The heavy rain-fall on Sunday made the track very heavy and several seconds slow.

M. Lavello, the daring young balloonist who exhibited his nerve in this city on Monday last, ascended from Victor yesterday, (Friday,) and gave the people of that quiet village an involuntary exhibition as magnificent in steadiness and coolness of nerve as one sees in a lifetime.

ALBANY, May 13. The Governor's action upon the Supply bill is not unfavorably raceived. The items vetood aggregate about $90,000. Some individuals are agreeably surprised to find that certain items which were expected to be vetoed have not been.

A cable dispatch announces the death at Versailes yesterdny of Col. Pierre Marie Philippe Aristide Denfert-Rochereau. This distinguished officer was born in January, 1823, and entered the Polytechnique School as early as his age permitted. In that famous institution, and at the Military School in Metz, he distinguished himself, and graduated from the latter school with the highest honors.
The balance in the City Treasury is $2,953,299 02. Murat Halstead, who an arrived from Liverpool in the steam-ship City of Richmond, left the Brevoort House last evening for Cincinnati.

Mr. Henry A. Bowen was arrested yesterday morning at his home, No. 55 Willow-street, Brooklyn, on a charge of abandonment preferred by his wife, Mrs. Lillie Bowen. The fact of his arrest excites a good deal of comment, because Mr. Bowen is a son of Mr. Edward E. Bowen, a well-known broker of this City, and a nephew of Henry C. Bowen, one of the most conspicuous figures in the Beecher-Tilton scandal.

Through experiments performed in the Universify of Berlin, Mackenzie and Nichols have arrived at the result that the increase of the volume of liquids through the absorption of gases is directy proportional to the quantity of gas absorbed.

The City of Cincinnati having very recently, by a popular vote, decided against issuing the "remaining" $2,000,000 of bonds for the Cincinnati Southern Railroad, and that enterprise being in several respects an anomalous one, a review of it may not be uninteresting.

A rather remarkable state of facts was developed yeaterday on a motion heard before Judge Choate, in the United States District Court, in bankruptcy, to set aside an injunction granted by Judge Choate on May 7 in the matter of the proceedings against the clothing firm of Keiler, Wormser Kingsbury, involuntary bankrupts.

Congress, in 1868, passed a bill to limit the hours of labor, in which it was declared that from that date eight hours should constitute a day's work for all laborers employed by the Government of the United States. This was considered at the time a great triumph for the oppressed and down-tredden laboring men.

The annual meeting of the Society for Ethical Culture was held last evening in Standard Hall, Mr. Joseph Soligman occupying the chair. He read the aunual report of the Secretary, showing that the Society began its existence in 1876 7, with a membership of 168, and an aggregate subscription list of $4,065.

The following letter from Acting Superintendent Lamb, of the State Bank Department, to President Macy, of the Seamen's Bank for Savings, is in answer to certain "statements which have recently been made by alleged committees of depositors," reflecting on the general system of savings bank management in this City.

Yesterday's proceedings in the British Parliament show the anxiety among the Liberals at the new departure of the Government with reference to the sending of Indian regiments to Europe. And there may well be deep fooling in England over this measure.

WASHINGTON, May 13. To-day's session of the Senate was devoted to the consideration of the Post Office Appropriation bill. After the bill proper had been disposed of, having undergone but very few alterations, Senator Maxey moved to amend by inserting a provision authorizing a subsidy to two lines of Amorican steamers to Brazil, once to sail from New-York and the other from New-Orleans.

WASHINGTON, May 13. The bill for the reorganization of the Army, as prepared by the House Committee on Appropriations, provides that the Ordnance. Engineer, Commissary, Quartermaster and Pay Departments, the Signal Service and artillery, are to be considered with a view to their reorganization by a board composed of three Major-Generals, who are to report on or before Dec. 1.

The trial of Rev. George B. Vosburgh, the Pastor of the Madison-Avenue Baptist Church, Jer sey City Heights, who is charged with having poisoned his invalid wife, was commenced in the Court of Oyer and Terminer, Jersey City, yesterday morning.

CINCINNATI, May 13. The city is gay with bunting and evergreens to-night in anticipation of the musical festival. Visitors are arriving on every train, and the hotels and lodging. houses are already crowded to excess.

Prof. Joseph Henry, of the Smithsonian Institution, died in Washington yesterday afternoon at 12:17 o'clock. He had keen identified with the advance of original investigation in physics in this country for so many years as to rank among the pioneers of American science. Joseph Henry was born at Albany, N.Y., Dec. 17, 1797, and had consequently completed his 80th year.

The session of the Senate was devoted mainly to the Post Office Appropriation bill. The amendments reported by tho Senate Committee on Appropriations were agreed to. The amendment of the Post Office Committee to subsidize the steam-ship lines to Brazil came up, and the discussion of a point of order as to the relevancy of the amendment occupied the rest of the session.

CINCINNATI, May 13. The Democrats at Columbus have made a desperate fight to-day for the Congressional redistricting scheme, and the present indications are that it will pass. The lower house passed the bill Saturday by a party vote, but when it came to the senate it met with violent opposition from soveral Domocratic members, who declared that they would never vote for it under any circumstances.
At the Herlem Police Court yesterday Philip Marsh was fined $10 for assualting Julius Block, of No. 153 East One Hundred and Thirteenth-street.

As much interest as there may be attached to the war between the contending railroads in the Grand Canon of the Arkansas, no occurrence has transpired in that locality which has attracted so much attention and sympathy as an accident which recently happened to Mrs. E.J. Mallett, of Canon City.

The 1st of May is devoted to a "private view" for the press. It is a privilege which is highly prized, enabling the art critics to do their work comfortably, unmolested by fashion, and with every facility for examining the pictures. The Council exact a promise that no notices of the works of art shall appear until after the customary and regular "private view," which takes place on the 3d or 4th of the month.

The members of the Stock Eachange yesterterday held their annual election, and it was by great odds the most exciting contest ever known in the history of the organization. The polls opened when the Exchange opened, and the excitement lasted until night, although the polls closed at 2:30 and the important results were declared before 5 o'clock.
Oregon has a debt largely in excess of the constitutional limit of $50,000. The Portland Oregonian says that it is mainly due to the Grover Administration, which was Democratic.
Before Register Ketchum, yesterday, there was opposition to the discharge from bankruptcy of Alexander Guthman.
On motion of Mr. REAGAN, of Texas, the House reconsidered the vote by which the main question was ordered on the bill to regulate interState commerce, and the bill went over until tomorrow.

MONTREAL, May 13. The Militia authorities are evidently in possession of information of a Fenian movement of some kind, and it is learned that the Twenty-third, Fiftieth, Fifty-first, Fifty-second, Fifty-third. Fifty-fourth, Fifty-fifth, Sixtieth, and Seventy-ninth Regiments, all at points near the frontier, have been served with large supplies of ball-cartridge.

Once more, the sublime has been converted into tho ridiculous. The investigation which was originally intended to oust Mr. HAYES from the Presidency and to install Mr. TILDEN in the office, has degenerated into a trumpery attempt to revive interest in the partisan scandals of the election in 1876, with poor TILDEN'S chances of a resurrection more slender than ever.

The cargo of the schooner Racehorse, which was siezed at Pier No. 8 East River, on Friday last, was sold by action yesterday afternoon for $2,000.

ALBANY, May 14. The Senate spent nearly the whole of the morning session in the third reading of bills. The first read was the bill for repaying Fifth-avenue from Fifty-ninth to Ninetieth streets, which was passed with only one negative vote Senator Robertson's. Mr. Hopkins expressed the opinion that it was unconstitutional, but nevertheless voted for it.

In one of the frontier towns of Texas near the Mexican border the regular Sunday afternoon bull-fights have latterly been varied by combats between a lion and a bull. There were two of these fights, and they attracted spectators from all the surrounding country.

The programme for the Spring meeting of the American Jockey Club was issued yesterday, and although there will be but five days' racing, the list furnishes a brilliant series of events. The opening day of the meeting has been set for day 30, (Decoration Day,) when five races will be decided, commencing as usual with a dash of three-quarters of a mile, for all ages, for a purse of $400.

LESINGTON, May 14. A heavy rain-fall, which lasted nearly all night, converted the racecourse into sticky mud, with no variety in it except in the depth. Besides this, a cold north wind, which penetrated the warmest overcoats, freightened off visitors to such an extent that the attendance was reduced fully two-thirds as compared with yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 14. It is evident from the tenor of the special dispatches from various portions of the West that the heavy frosts of last Saturday and Sunday nights have resulted in some damage to some of the growing crops.

BOSTON, May 23. The trial of the Taylor divorce suit was resumed to-day, it having been found impossible for the opposing parties to come to an agreement out of court. It is understood that Mrs. Taylor would agree to modest alimony if she could have the custody of her child and be separated from her husband, and Mr. Taylor would agree to anything, if Mrs. Taylor would agree to come back to him.

The statistical records of marine underwriting are rarely brought to the notice of the public. Unlike life and fire insurance, the business, though an important one, is limited in its extent. Men engaged in every occupation insure their lives and property as a means of protection in case of death or fire; but marine policies are taken out by those only who own vessels or who export or import merchandise.

A drug store is to be opened at Coney Island during the present month.
TRENTON, June 4. The attendance at the opening of the June term of the New-Jersey Supreme Court, which took place to-day, was unusually large.

The Board of Aldermen were mainly engaged at their meeting yesterday in considering measures intended to cripple the power of the Department of Public Works, in retaliation for the refusal of Commissioner Campbell to give them a portion of his patronage, and also on account of the course he has pursued in relation to street obstructions.

The second opening this season at the dry goods establishment of J. C. Johnston, Broadway, Fifth-avenue and Twenty-second-street, occurred yesterday, and consisted of a magnificent display of made-up white goods, imported expressly for the occasion.

WASHINGTON, June 4. The Tariff bill was considered in the House to-day, and will be finally disposed of to-morrow. Before going into Committee of the Whole to consider the bill, a contest occurred over the question of limiting debate. Mr. Wood wanted the time fixed at four hours.

On motion, the select committee on affairs between Mexico and the United States was continued till the next session, and authorized to sit during recess. The bill for the relief of Collector Arthur was favorably reported.

ST. LOUIS, June 4. The first running meeting of the St. Louis Jockey and Trotting Club began today at their new course, in the western suburbs, about five miles from the centre of the city. The weather was fine, the track in good condition, and the attendance large.

The Sho-wae-cae-mette four-oared crew, who are to represent America at Henley, on the Thames, next month, arrived in this City yesterday morning from Watkins, where they have remained since the conclusion of the test regatta.

The divorce case of Lena Shillak against Jacob Shillak was made the subject of a decision by Judge Sedgwick in Superior Court, Special Term, yesterday. The parties to the action were married on Feb. 25, 1876. Mrs. Shillak then gave her husband $500 with which to go into business.

The opening of the Metropolitan Elevated Railway was yesterday the occasion of a good deal of excitement along the entire line of the road. The company was not entirely prepared to begin operations, and it was, therefore, unable to do all that an impatient public was anxious should be done.

WASHINGTON, June 5. The enacting clause of Mr. Wood's Tariff bill was struck out in the House to-day, by a vote of 134 to 120, which effectually kills the measure and makes it certain that no further revison of the tariff will be attempted during the sessions of the Fortyfifth Congress.
