SAN FRANCISCO, June 8. A dispatch from Silver City, Idaho, states that about 40 hostile Bannock Indians are camped at Juniper Creek, 10 miles from South Mountain. They were discovered yesterday by a friendly Indian. Capt. Harper, who left here last night with 20 Home Guards, sent here this morning for reinforcements, which will be sent forward immediately. If these Bannocks remain where they are, Harper will certainly attack them to-night or to-morrow morning.

NEWBURG, N. Y., June 10.--Reports from the Ulster County fruit districts indicate an unusually large-sized growth of strawberries. Growers state that the recent rains and cool weather produced this result. In some instances three or four berries are sufficient to fill a one-third cup. The bulk of the crop along the Valley of the Hudson will be ready for shipment during the latter part of this week.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., June 11. Dennis Donnelly, the Mollie Maguire convicted of planning the murder of Thomas Sanger at Raven Run, on Sept. 1, 1875, was hanged here this morning. His death warrant fixed April 18 as the day for the esecution, but he was respited until to-day to give him more time to prepare for death.

TROY, June 12.--The regatta of the Upper Hudson Regatta Association opened to-day, and will continue through to-morrow. The weather was fine. A large crowd assembled at the starting point, and both sides of the river were lined with spectators. The races were rowed over a new course, surveyed last Winter, which the majority of oarsmen present consider very short.

WASHINGTON, June 12.--The Senate today passed the General Deficiency bill without amendment, and precisely as it was passed by the House. This is the first time in the history of Congress that such a course has been taken with a measure of such magnitude and importance, the amount appropriated being nearly$6,000,000.

GOLDSBORO', N.C., June 14. Noah Cherry, Harris Atkinson, and Robert Thompson, the colored murderers of the Worley family, were hanged at 3 P.M. to-day in the presence of 6,000 people. They proclaimed their innocence to the last, and were very defiant and bitter toward the prosecuting attorneys. Everything passed off quietly. The necks of Cherry and Atkinson were broken, and Thompson was strangled to death.

A looker-on in the convention yesterday could not but have been struck with the earnestness and grit of the representatives of the western Democracy. They were overwhelmed in the convention. The predominant sentiment of the party was adverse to their choice, and they were compelled to stand up before their countrymen and see their idol sacrificed and shattered in their very presence.

LONG BRANCH, June 16. About 500 visitors spent Sunday pleasantly at Long Branch. Some of these came down on Saturday night, but the majority were excursionists who sailed to Sandy Hook on the stamer Crystal Wave, and came thence by a train on the Southern Railroad this morning. The day was perfect, and, most of the hotels being open, the visitors had every opportunity for enjoyment.

The excitement of the Berlinese is more easily imagined than described. The Constitution of the United States provides that "all bills for raising revenue shall originate in the House of Representatives." CAMDEN, N.J., June 17. The first week of the trial of Benjamin Hunter for the murder of John M. Armstrong has passed, and the coil of evidence has been so tightened about the accused that it seems almost impossible for the keen lawyers who are conducting his side of the case to loosen it.

CAMDEN, N. J., June 18.--The testimony for the prosecution in the trial of Hunter was concluded this afternoon, and the opening was made for the defense, foreshadowing an alibi as the chief point on, which the case will rest in Hunter's favor. SCHENECTADY, June 26. The Commencement exercises of Union College held here to-day were of more than usual interest.

The meeting of the Alumni this morning was called to order at 9:30, and Hon. Dwight Foster, of Boston, was invited to preside. He introduced the oldest living graduate of the college, Major Peirce, of the Class of 1806, and of Cornwall, Conn., who was in the ninety-second year of his age.
William F. Cody, one of the men injured in the explosion in the Tax Office Monday morning last was somewhat improved yesterday.

ROCHESTER, June 26. Judgment in the suit brought by Charles Coots, of this city, against the Globe Mutual Life Insurance Company, of New-York, has just been recorded in the County Clerk's office.

WEST POINT, June 26. Anson Maltby, counsel for Gen. Fitz John Porter, continued his statement this morning, beginning with the consideration of the chargo of Porter's disobeying Pope's order, at 4:30 P. M., on Aug. 29, 1862, to attack the enemy at the second battle of Bull Run. Counsel said, in substance, that Porter, at the time named, was in front of the Southern forces at Manassas.

The Commencement exercises of the Wesleyan University at Middletown, Conn., took place yesterday in the Methodist Episcopal Church.

Slosson, of Chicago, and was won by Sexton in 21 innings, by a score of 600 to 338.

Henry Schmidt, a German carpenter, of unprepossessing appearance, was placed on trial in Part I. of the Court of General Sessions yesterday, charged with having administered poison to his wife Barbara, his daughter Katrina, 14 years of age, and his mother-in-law, Mrs. Schmittler.

NEW-LONDON, June 27. The third annual eight-oared shell race over a four-mile course, between the University-crews of Harvard and Yale, is to be rowed on the Thames River at this place to-morrow morning at 11 o'clock, wind and weather permitting.

FREEHOLD, N. J., June 27. The centennial fever is prevalent in historic Monmouth. Everybody in this old town is in a state of excitement, which finds its fullest expression in the exhibition of red, white, and blue bunting.

The New-York Presbyterian Church has had a mortgage on its property in West Eleventh street, between Sixth and Seventh avenues, for the past five years amounting to $14,000. The debt was incurred by the church to complete the erection of the present building in West Eleventh-street.

The hearing in the Vanderbilt will contest was resumed before Surrogate Calvin yesterday. Almost the entire day was consumed in the crossexamination of Prof. F.H. Hamilton, the medical expert, by Mr. Clinton.

There has been no lack of emotional amusements for the Parisians since last Sunday; I say emotional, because everything is emotional to this population; and I say amusements, because, whether it be a wedding march or a funeral procession, the explosion of a powder magazine, a review, or a horse-race, anything out of the common way is hailed with satisfaction as affording matter for conversation and criticism.

A circular was issued yesterday to the holders of the 7 per cent, gold bonds and certificates of the Kansas Pacific Railway Company, which are commonly called the Denver Extension bonds, by the Committee of Nine of First Mortgage Bondholders of the road.
Mr. FRANCIS PARKMAN, the well-known historian, contributes to the current number of the North American Review an able and thoughtful article on "The Failure of Universal Suffrage."

Yesterday was in some places the very hottest day of the season. For a week the heat had been of the most intemperate and uncalled-for character, but yesterday the solar furnace was poked and the blower put on until the heat became so great that, if rumor speaks truly, Mr. CHARLES FRANCIS ADAMS himself was thoroughy warmed through.

The drama of "Diplomacy," like many of the other plays composed by foreign authors, has brought about a lawsuit, resulting from an attempt, as is claimed, to produce an unauthorized version in San Francisco.

CAMDEN, N.J., July 3. At 4:30 o'clock this afternoon, the case of Benjamin Hunter was given to the jury. The final argument for the State was made by District Attorney Richard S. Jenkins, who occupied the attention of the court until shortly after 3 o'clock, when the charge of Judge Woodhull to the jury was begun.

A match between the St. George's Club, of this City, and the Young America, of Philadelphia, was played on the grounds of the former at Hobokon, N.J., yesterday afternoon. The Philadelphians sent over a strong team, embracing four of the brothers Newhall; St. George's had but a fair 11.

Tho particular feature of the week has been the commemoration of President Anderson's quarter-centennial on Tuesday evening when the usual Alumni literary exercises were dispensed with, and Corinthian Hall was filled with the eminent President's admirers and friends.

The noise of the fire-cracker, the blaze of fire works, and the movement of excursion parties throughout the State were about the only celebration accorded to the national anniversary day in New-Jersey. There was a little parade in New Brunswick.

LONDON, July, 4. The Times' correspondent at Constantinople confirms the report that Gen. Todleben formed, on Tuesday, a commission of staff officers to establish three lines of retreat on Adrianople.

WASHINGTON, July 4. John Wilson, United States Consul at Brussels, in a dispatch to the Department of State, dated June 14, 1878, gives some hints as to the methods of introducing American manufactures into Europe. He starts out with the assertion that prejudice is a greater obstacle than tariffs or unregulated trade.

Dr. William F. Carver, who for years past has astonished the Pacific Slope by his marvelous feats of markmanship, gave his first exhibition of rifle-shooting yesterday in this vicinity at the Brooklyn Driving Park.

About 5,000 persons, from New-York and Connecticut, visited Sea Cliff, on the Sound, yesterday, in the dual character of excursionists and participators in a grand Rhode Island clam-bake. There were, of course, other attractions offered, in the way of prayer, singing, an oration, and the reading of the Declaration of Independence, but the clam-bake was what the people went for, and it was the first and last thing spoken of.

Not since Donnelly, the keeper of the Oceanic Hotel here, murdered one of his guests for the purpose of robbing him, and fired the house containing the mangled body to destroy the evidence of his crime, has such a cool and atrocious murder been perpetrated as that which occurred at Jenkinson's hotel last evening.

A large and exceedingly sonerous brass band acted the part of a Mohammedan muezzin yesterday morning in calling the faithful adherents of Tammany Hall to the Wigwam in Fourteenth-street, where the usual ceremonies in honour of Independence Day were gone through with. The match between the St. George's Cricket Club and the Young America, of Philadelphia, was concluded at Hoboken yesterday, resulting in a most disastrous defeat for the home team.

Last year 24 veterans of the war of 1812 gathered under the flag that floated at the mizzen peak of the Bonhomme Richard in her battle with the Serapis. Yesterday there were but 17. Adjutant J. Gould Warner was stirring long before daylight, as usual.

For the first time in the present century the Fourth of July in the City of New-York has come and gone without any of the usual accessories of the day. No Sunday this Summer has presented such an interminable array of deserted streets and thoroughfares as will have to be recorded of the great national holiday in the Metropolis of the United States, with all its historic landmarks and its Revolutionary associations.

PITTSBURGH, July 4. The day just past has been one of the most quiet anniversaries ever celebrated in this city. The weather was intensely warm in the morning, but about 3 o'clock a severe thunder and rain storm struck the city, causing considerable damage in suburban districts.

WOODSTOCK, Conn., July 4. The Fourth of July celebrations of this ancient town have come to be almost a matter of national concern, owing to be eminent speakers who, on so many of these occasions during the past 20 years, have accepted invitations to come here and express their views upon public affairs.

THOMPSON, who, to use his own expression, is "not only Sergeant-at-Arms of the House of Representatives, but also Chairman of the Buckeye Unterrified," goes about exhorting the faithful to "claim everything, put the majorities high, and hold on till the end."

WASHINGTON, July 4. There was no formal celebration of the Fourth in Washington, and the city presented even a duller appearance than is usual on Sundays. The executive departments were closed and salutes were fired at sunrise and sunset by the troops at the Arsenal, but beyond this no notice was taken by the authorities of the national anniversary.

Justice Morgan was in a forgiving mood, and listened to the pleadings of a neatlydressed child whoso pretty hat did not reach the top of the desk for her erring father.

Half an hour before daybreak yesterday a free fight took place between a party of young roughs in Prince-street, near Greene, culminating in the fatal stabbing of James Dougherty, a butcher, aged 20, of No. 221 Sullivan-street.

SKANEATELES, July 4. About 15,000 people witnessed the Courtney-Dempsey single scull race on Skaneateles Lake. The course was five miles two and one-half miles and return. The water was in good condition. Commodore C. H. Poore, Jr., of Skaneateles, was referee. Courtney first caught the water, gradually gaining and turning the stake 40 lengths ahead, keeping the same distance to finish, winning in 40:48. Dempsey's time was 41:58.

A painful report has been circulated concerning the plan adopted for paying the experts of Mr. GLOVER's committee for their valuable and patriotic services. It appeals that Congress, with a culpable disregard of the claims of those gentlemen upon its gratitude and the public Treasury, failed to make an appropriation for paying them.

The head-quarters of the Division of the Atlantic will be removed to-day from this City to Governer's Island. Hitherto the Atlantic Division of the United States Army has comprised three departments, namely, that of the Atlantic States, that of the South, and that of the Gulf.

Shortly before 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon a fire broke out in the junk shop of John Garay, No. 543 West Fifty-second-street, and extended to several adjoining buildings, causing over $9,000 damage. The loss of Garay on stock and building is estimated at $2,000; no insurance.

A collection of drawings by Mr. Ruskin is now to be seen at the Fine Art Society's Galleries, New Bond-street, together with those masterpieces of Turner's art which we have already noticed briefly. Mr. Ruskin's drawings serve as a tolerably complete art-autobiography, delineating the author's progress in drawing from an early period of his life to the present day.

One of the principal burglars engaged in the robbery of the jewelry store of Mr. Simon I. Rodberg, No. 190 West Baltimore-street, some months ago, when $18,000 worth of goods were carried off, has been hunted down, and is now in Auburn, N. Y., State Prison.

PORTLAND, Oregon, July 4. The following was received here from N.A. Connoyer, Indian Agent, Pendleton, dated Monday night: Some of the Umatillas have just arrived in haste. The Snakes are within 60 miles of this place, killing all they meet. It is feared that some Indian families are killed. Two Indian runners arrived this evening.

The Greenbackers of the Fifth District of Maine have nominated Thompson Murch for Congress. He is the Secretary of the National Stonecutters' Union, and has been a Democrat.

Rev. Dr. John Dowling, who was sent to the New-York State Homeopathic Asylum for the Insane, at Middletown, on Monday, June 24, died in that institution yesterday afternoon at 6:15 o'clock. The record of the earliest races shows that the oarsmen of 30 years ago knew how to handle their boats and oars, although their time has been greatly improved upon.

LOUISVILLE, July 4. At 10 o'clock this morning the streets were well-high impassable. The buildings were handsomely decorated, and unparalleled interest was felt in the great event of the day. The first race was a dash of a mile and three quarters, and was won by Dank, beating Harkaway easily. Time-2:18 .

The Seventy-ninth Highlanders, Old Guard, celebrated the Fourth with a picnic at Elm Park, Ninety-second-street, near Eighth-avenue. In the morning, previous to the festivities at Elm Park, the Guard to the number of about 60, by special request, escorted the Hudson County Calodonian Club from Jersey City to the Schuetzen Park, where the annual Scottish games were to be held.

LONDON, July 5. The Columbias have won the only boat race ever gained by an American crew in England, and are the heroes of Henley. That they are a good crew has been ail along admitted, but the superb form they have shown for the past two days surprised even their best friends.

MONTREAL, July 5. A meeting of Justices of the Peace of the city and district took place to-day, to consider the best means of preserving the peace of the city on the 12th of July, Two hundred magistrates were present, W.H. Brehant, the Chairman, briefly stated that he was ready to hear any one who desired to speak.

PITTSBURG, July 5. The storm which swept over this city and the vicinity yesterday afternoon proves to have been the most destructive one in loss of life and property that has occurred here for several years. In the city several houses were struck by lightning, and the flood of water did great damage, but no lives were lost.

The joy in this City over the victory of the Columbia crew on the Thames, is universal and heartfelt. It pervades all classes, and the praise of the crew is sounded on all sides by people who never before heard of them.

Rev. James Harkness, D.D. M.D., died at his home on Mercer street, Jersey City, Wednesday. Born in Roxburyshire, Scotland, in 1803, he was 75 years of age at the time of his decease. Dr. Edward Seguin, who is one of the Professors in the College of Physicians and Surgeons, has, with the aid and countenance of the New-York Academy of Sciences, set on foot a movement to render the public parks of this City subservient to an educational purpose of considerable magnitude.

The report which was circulated yesterday to the effect that a large number of the men at work on the anchorage and approaches of the East River Bridge, on the New-York side, had been discharged, proved on investigation to be only partially correct.
Schedules were filed yesterday in the matter of the assignment of Jacob Brush, clothier, of No. 532 Grand-street, to John C. Rapp. The liabilities are $24,069 29 and the assets $1,571 19.

A gentlemanly-looking porson, who has boarded at the Carrollton Hotel for the past two weeks, registering himself as Edward Everett, of Boston, Mass., was arrested Saturday, charged with passing a bogus check for $60 on a clerk in the house, and after an examination before Justice Johns, at the Middle Station, was committed for action by the Grand Jury.

In company with several other Confederate officers, I arrived in the City of Mexico after a journey of some 1,300 miles, principally on horseback, weary and worn, ill-clad and scantily supplied with money; but we slept in peace and security for the first time for four long years. The relief from the cares and responsibilities which had pressed upon us so incessantly during the whole of this period was inexpressibly grateful.

In pursuance of the systematic plan for the preparation of a topographical atlas of the entire area west of the one hundredth meridian, parties of this survey are now taking the field for the season of 1878, in Utah, Nevada, California, Oregon, Colorado, New-Mexico, Arizona, and Texas.

For the first time since 1872 the Democracy of Georgia finds itself confronted with a formidable foe. The progress of Georgia politics since the war is too familiar to need relating now; it is a history which has been repeated in every Southern State, in which, after a brief but violent struggle, the wealth and intelligence, as in the case of the Saxons and Celts in Ireland, forged to the lead.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 9. The Nashville department of the National Cotton Exchange has received 23 replies from Middle Tennessee. Seventeen report too much rain and cool weather since June 1, and 6 report that the weather has been favorable and the rains have not retarded cultivation.

SARATOGA, July 9. There has been a great gathering of the Vanderbilt business family here to-day, and the register of the United States Hotel is filled with the names of men who are connected directly or indirectly with the interests of the New-York Central Railroad.

BERLIN, July 9. It is believed the congress decided that while Russia receives Batoum as a free port, the territory principally inhabited by the Lazis is excepted from Russian control. In return for this concession, the British plenipotentiaries accepted the substitution of the expression "essentially commercial," instead of "exclusively commercial," as applied to the port of Batoum.

It is still a mooted question among men of science whether a large proportion of the deaths attributed to hydrophobia are not the result of delusion. A nervous person is playfully bitten by a pet terrier, and straightway the unfortunate animal is regarded with suspicion. The sudden change of behavior toward him, curiously enough, causes him to "act strangely," and he is presently accused of being mad.

Ex-Senator Boutwell, who is understood to be one of the candidates for the succession to Butler in Congress from the Seventh District, came before the public to-day, for the first time since his return from Washington, in an address at the Commencement of the Worcester Free Institute of Industral Science at Worcester.

DETROIT, July 10. The Democratic State Convention met at the Opera-house in Lansing at noon to-day, and was called to order by D.M. Dickinson, Chairman of the State Central Committee. Dr. Foster Pratt was chosen temporary Chairman.

MONTREAL, July 10. The committee appointed at the French and Irish meetings held here last night waited upon the Mayor to-day, and presented the resolutions of confidence in him which were passed. Major Alexander Hamilton Sibley, of Detroit, Mich., died suddenly yesterday morning of apoplexy at the New-York Hotel. Major Sibley was born in Detroit in October, 1817. Upon leaving school he was employed as a messenger for the Bank of Michigan.

The remains of George S. Appleton, of the firm of D. Appleton Co., publishers, were followed to Green-Wood Cemetery yesterday afternoon by a large number of relatives, friends, and employes, and deposited in the same vault that contains the ashes of Daniel Appleton, formerly the head of the house.
William Barry, a boy, was prostrated by the heat while riding through Ege-avenue, Jersey City, yesterday. His recovery is regarded as doubtful.
The investigation of the East Forty-secondstreet tunnel accident, by which Thomas Joyco and Patrick Lynch lost their lives, was resumed yesterday by Coroner Woltman.

Moritz Hollender, a peddler, was arrested yesterday on a charge of selling cigars upon which no tax or duty had been paid. He was committed by United States Commissioner Shields to await examination, bail being fixed at $250.

The Seventh-Avenue Railroad Company, following in the wake of its neighbor, the SixthAvenue Railroad, have resolved to do away with the cars at present in use on their road, and substitute for them one-horse conveyances, or what is generally known as "bob-tail" cars.

Gen. ARTHUR was appointed Collector of the . port of New-York, for a term of four years, in November, 1871, and the appointment was received with marked approval on all sides. MONTREAL, July 11. Excitement increases as the Orange anniversary approaches, and deep anxiety is depicted on every countenance one meets in the streets. The Mayor, who has declared that there shall be no procession, is resolved not to be superseded, and will have command of the City Police and a body of 500 special constables, who are to be sworn in to-day.

Daniel Dempsey, of Jericho, who brutally assaulted his wife with a club on Tuesday night, was yesterday taken to the Insane Asylum at Utica by Superintendent Franklin, of Oyster Bay. Dempsey is violently insane, superinduced by liquor. On Sunday and Monday both himself and wife had been drinking hard, Mrs. Dempsey is still confined to her house from the wounds inflicted by her husband.

WASHINGTON, July 17 1 A.M. The pressure is highest and nearly stationary along the Atlantic Coast. A trough of low pressure extends from Nebraska to Lake Superior. Light rains have fallen in Minnesota and Wisconsin; elsewhere, clear or partly cloudy weather prevails. The temperature has remained nearly stationary.

AUBURN, N.Y., July 16. The Owasco Lake course is rapidly growing in favor with oarsmon, and Auburn is proportionately happy. The lake is comparatively small, well protected from wind, and one of the mostbeautiful of the Central Now-York group.

Mr. Joseph Pool, President of the Manufacturers' and Merchants' Bank of this City, is now conducting a suit-against Mr. Stephen Higginson, a well-to-do coffee merchant, for damages, and to comper the discontinuance of an alleged nuisance.

WASHINGTON, July 16. The recent changes at the New-York Custom-house were informally discussed to-day at the Cabinet meeting. Secretary Sherman related his experiences in New-York in connection with the matter, but was unable to explain the popular condemnation that swiftly followed the suspension of Gen. Arthur and Mr. Cornell.

There is a balance in the City Treasury of $339,835 09. A certificate was filed yesterday in the County Clerk's office, showing that the Brooklyn Trust Company had reduced its capital, as authorized by the last Legislature, to $251,875.

Kate Claxton, the actress, has applied to Register Fitch for her discharge from bankraptcy, and the Register has notified the creditors to appear on Aug. 6 to show cause why she should not receive her discharge.

RALEGH, N.C., July 16 Contrary to general expectation the Nationals are beginning to take root in this State. It was not thought that any man of suffcient character and ability could be induced to espouse the cause of the new party.

Five steam-ships are to sail for Murope today viz., the ville de Paris, of the French Line, for Havre; the Abyssinia, of the Canard Line, for Liverpool; the Italy, of the National Line, and the Alsatia of the Anchor Line, for London, and the Maas, of the Netherlands-American Line, for Rotterdam.

About two months ago the Bee contained a brief report of recent fossil discoveries in the Rocky Mountains, near Como Station, on the Union Pacific Railroad. These discoveries have proved to be of much greater importance to the scientific world than many who are well versed in geology had supposed.

Our friend "George" was right about the London Rowing Club. They come to Henley for the Stewards' Challenge Cup, and they usually take it away. When the gentleman of the Columbia crew whom I interviewed spoke of the from and style of the English boating men he had not seen the four whom the London, Rowing Club had sent to Henley.

The homes of the Now-England Senators afford the Boston Herald a theme for some interesting descriptive gossip. These are mostly of a very unpretentious character. The residence of Senator Dawes, at Pittsfield, Mass., is a large, square, brown mansion of wood, the south windows of which command a beautiful prospect of the valley of the Housatonic and of the Hoosac Mountains.

Conferences took place yesterday between a committee of gentlemen representing the proportyowners of the north-western end of Manhattan Island and the Directors of the New-York Elevated Railroad and the Metropolitan Elevated Railway, with reference to the extension of rapid transit through that section of the island.

The pseudo Lady Trevylaine, whose history was exclusively published in yesterday's TIMES, spent yesterday in swinging backward and forward, with a nonchalant air, in one of the cool prison cells of Jefferson Market, and looking pensively at the celling. She wore the same striped gray suit she was attired in when arrested. The coat was unbattoned, and revealed a locket fastened with a pink ribbon in her waistcost.

There was nothing new to be learned yesterday in relation to the motive for the singular suicide of the wealthy young merchant, James Lally, who shot himself on Monday at Mrs. Coombs' country villa at Riverdale, on the Hudson.

VINCENNES, Ind., July 19. Notwithstanding that a light breeze prevailed today and the thermometer was several degrees lower, the cases of prostration were as numerous as on the previous days. Horses are wearing damp sponges for protection, and the citizens generally are confining themselves within doors as much as possible.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 26.--Gen. Garfield was prevented from resuming his testimony before the Potter committee to-day, having experienced a sudden attack of vertigo while bathing in the surf this morning, in company with Congressmen Springer and Hiscock.

SARATOGA, July 26.--To-morrow will be the fourth day of the race meeting, and though it may be considered an off day, the prospect for good sport is excellent. The card calls for only three races, but one of them is a heat race, which will fill out the programme to the usual length.

WASHINGTON, July 30.--According to announcements heretofore made, the Dominion of Canada became a member of the Postal Union on the 1st of July. Shortness of notice, however, prevented the Canadian postal authorities from putting into operation on that date the provisions of the Postal Union treaty, and the United States Post Office Department has received notice from the Canadian office that postal union exchanges will commence in Canada on the 1st of August next.

Merchants of this City who have business connections with China and Japan, and who dispatched letters for their correspondents in those countries by the mail that left this City on Saturday last, will undoubtedly be embarrassed by the delay which will take place in the delivery of their communications.

The cases of Civil Justices Pinckney and Flanagan were taken up by the Supreme Court. General Term, yesterday, that being the day appointed for the Justices to show cause why they should not be removed for malfeasance in office. Judges Ingalls, Potter, and Daniels were on the bench.

TORONTO, Ontario, July 30.--In an article on the new Governor-General, the Globe says: "The appointment of the Marquis of Lorne to the Governorship of Canada is one of the surprises in which the Prime Minister of England delights. We doubt whether any Administration less enterprising would have conceived the idea of sending a son-in-law of the Queen to this country.

WASHINGTON, July 30.--Attempts are being made in some quarters to censure the Interior Department for failing to furnish the Indians with the supplies to which they are entitled by law and treaty stipulations, and to place on the department, in consequence of this failure, the responsibility for the present Indian disturbances.

PORTLAND, July 30.--The Republican State Convention held in this city to-day, was the largest Republican Convention held in Maine since the close of the war. The delegations were full and the attendance of interested spectators very large.

Heinrich C. Ritz, a small, pale young man, went to board in the family of Henry Frecking in September, 1876. Mr. Frecking has a comely daughter, named Henriette, now about 18 years old, to whom Ritz became attached.

The steam-ships which are to sail for Europe today are the Labrador, of the French Line; the Algeria, of the Cunard Line; the Elysia, of the Anchor Line, and the Denmark, of the National Line. Havre and Liverpool are the respective ports of destination of the first two vessels. The other two are bound for London.

Cardoze and Lieut. Vinot participated, and which terminated in a great uproar, a charge upon sundry of the station doors, and a final assault upon the station agent.

LONDON, July 30.--The debate in the House of Commons last night on Lord Hartington's resolution is described on all sides as dull and spiritless. It was adjourned at an early hour. Some persons have even expressed the hope that the debate would be concluded tonight, but it is generally expected to close on Thursday.
Register Little yesterday reported in favor of the discharge from bankruptcy of Arthur L. Sewell, of the late firm of John Bonner Co., bankers and brokers, there being no opposition by the creditors.

With the passing years, increased facilities for communication with the outside world, and the general spread of education, the people of even the remote districts of the far Southern States are beginning to take more enlightened views of life and to lose taste for many or the old and semi-barbarous customs which at one time prevailed among them.
LONDON, July 30.--The little craft Nautilus, from Boston, 45 days out, passed the Scilly Islands yesterday, and was sighted this evening approaching Falmouth.

The convention of the Republicans of Maine, which was held at Portland yesterday, dispatched its work with commendable promptness. The character of the proceedings, contrasted with those of a year ago, indicates in a somewhat striking manner the change that has taken place in political feeling.

BERLIN, July 31. In the elections for members of the German Parliament yesterday the National Liberals were successful at Hamburg, Leipsic, and Augsburg. A second ballot will be necessary at Hanover between a Particularist and a Socialist candidate, and at Munich between a National Liberal and a Clerical candidate.

William Rockwell, of No. 402 West Twenty-third-street, answered the advertisement, and called at No. 2 Clinton-place, as directed. He there met Joshua Carpenter, who said he was making preparations to open an extensive fancygrocery store.

Nature never does anything without an intelligent purpose. For example, the eye, as Dr. PALEY has demonstrated at great length and in the most conclusive manner, was made to see with. So, too, man was furnished with a mustache in order that the crackling noise made by it when it takes fire from a match while he is in the act of relighting a cigar-stump may warn him to withdraw his nose from the flames.

Somebody has been counting the carriages in Newport. Between 6:30 and 7 o'clock there passed the Ocean House 105 carriages, of which two were fours-in-hand, 2 tandems, 21 singles, and 80 pairs. Of these only 10 pairs and two single turnouts were hired. The 105 carriages carried 64 iveried servants. Messrs. George R. Fearing and Augustus Whitney drove the fours-in-hand. Mr. J.N.A. Griswold drove one of the tandems.

The removal of Collector Arthur has been followed by another Governmental change of an almost similar character. Last Winter one of the "civil service reforms" projected was the degradation of Special Treasury Agent Brackett, whose exceptional energy and success in the work of ferreting out and punishing those engaged in defrauding the revenue has made his name known throughout the country.
Alfred Storms, hotel-keeper at No. 48 Chatham-street, applied to Register Ketchum yesterday for his discharge from bankruptcy. No creditors opposed it and his discharge will be granted.

LONDON, Saturday, July 20, 1878. Is it surprising that Gladstone hates him? "The People's William" bites his lips in the shadow of a permanent unpopularity. "Dizzy" basks in the sunshine of an imperial fame. William Ewart Gladstone, Esq., M.P., consorts with Irish adventurers "below the gangway."

The Dowling Challenge Cup, valued at $1.50, is to be sailed for to-day over a 15-mile course, starting from the foot of One Hundred and Fourth-street and East River. The race is open to all jib and mainsail boats under 20 feet, and the number of entries is very large.
The shirt-ironers in the employ of Johnston Sutphen, Newark, have struck for an increase of wages.

SELL SAGE'S VENTURE IN LAKE SHORE. For two days Wall-street has been in a state of ferment, filled with rumors of an impending panic. Up to the close of business yesterday, however, the panic had not come, although there had been as abundance of exciting talk all day long, up and down "the street," in the Exchange, and everywhere a knot of brokers was found together.
Dante T. Rosetti writes to the London Times and the Athenaeum warning the public that spurious drawings purporting to be by him are offered for sale in some of the shops.

BUFFALO, July 31. This was the first day of the Buffalo races. The first race, for the 2:34 class, was short and decisive, Dame Trot winning easily in three straight heats, beating her performance at Cleveland. As the day was windy, the time made was considered excellent.

LONDON, July 31. The delegates of the American Young Men's Christian Association to the Geneva Congress arrived in London yesterday, and were entertained at breakfast this morning at the rooms of the London association, in Aldersgate-street. A general meeting of welcome to the American delegates will be held Friday evening. On Monday they will proceed to Paris.

A team of the St. George's Cricket Club commenced a two days' match with an eleven of the Merion Club, Philadelphia, on the Hoboken ground, yesterday. The visitors were first to bat, and sent forward Morris and Haines. It was a very dead wicket, and hard for scoring. Three singles were made in Giles' first over, another single in Moeran's, and half a dozen throws afterward Morris was bowled.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 1. The debt statement for July, the first month of the new fiscal year, shows a decrease of only $206,000, against $800,000 for July, 1877, and $1,100,000 for July, 1876. The slight decrease for the month just closed is attributable to the large amount disbursed during that period, which exceeded $14,000,000.

Aiming as it does to furnish a post-graduate university course to the alumni of American colleges, its progress in number of students must necessarily be slow. Alessandro Franchi, Cardinal, Pontifical Secretary of State, and Archbishop of Thessalonia, died in Rome at 1 o'clock yesterday morning. He was born June 15, 1819, in Rome. The son of a notary, be retained the habits of that profession after his admission to the priesthood, being exceedingly methodical, yet clever, affable, witty, making many friends, yet never losing a coign of vantage.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Aug. 1. The State Democratic Convention met to-day, with full quotas of delegates from all the counties. Gen. John D. Kennedy was unanimously elected President of the convention. CINCINNATI, Aug. 2.--Advices from Southeastern Indiana state that a tornado swept over that section of the country yesterday, damaging crops, trees, and buildings seriously. At Liberty, Ind., the Methodist Church was badly injured, and the residence of J.M. Darco partially burned. LONDON, Aug. 2. In the House of Commons, this evening, the debate on Lord Hartington's resolution was resumed. Lord Elcho, Conservative member for Haddingtonshire, violently attacked the Opposition, attributing the Russo-Turkish war to their conduct.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2. President Keep has just returned from a trip over the North-western Road and all its tributaries. As he carefully examined the crop prospects in regions where the greatest damage has been done by unfavorable weather; his conclusions are interesting.

The City of Chester, of the Inman Line, will be ready to sail at 10 o'clock to-morrow morning, making her delay from the accident to her propeller only three days. One hundred and fifty saloon passengers have already been booked for this vessel.

BUFFALO, Aug. 2. The third day of the Fall meeting of the Buffalo Park Association was very successful. The two unfinished races of yesterday, and the 2:30 class and free for all races of to-day, furnished a full programme of sport for those in attendance, who numbered about 7,000.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Aug. 2. Gen. A.L. Roumfort, a native of Paris, France, but for over three-quarters of a century a citizen of Pennsylvania, died in this city this afternoon of dropsy, after a long and painful illness, in the eighty-second year of his age. He was graduated at West Point in 1817, and was, with one exception, the oldest living graduate of that institution.

The Erie Railway Company issued, several years ago, bonds to the amount of 1,200,000, which were taken up in the London market. WASHINGTON, July 31.--A review of Army organization as it existed in 1861, after the breaking out of the rebellion, discloses many interesting facts and reminiscences. Tomeny, of Arkansas, was summoned before Glover and his experts to give evidence touching the disposition of certain cotton captured by the United States military forces during the rebellion, and which was placed in his charge as a Special Agent of the Treasury Department.

Michael Kenney, an upholsterer, aged 25 years, of No. 382 Hudson-avenue, Brooklyn, and his brother Matthew, aged 23 years, of South Fourth and Fifth streets, Williamsburg, were assaulted and terribly beaten, late on Saturday night, by a gang of roughs.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 4.--During a light shower this afternoon the place of worship of the Ridge-Avenue Methodist Episcopal congregation, at Ridge-avenue and Diamond-street, in the north-western part of the city, was struck by lightning and demolished. The services were conducted in a tent, and, as the time drew near for the opening of the Sunday-school, the children assembled.

The tragedy at No. 107 Allen-street on Saturday night, the leading facts of which were given yesterday, possesses certain aspects of more than ordinary interest. From the account given by the landlord it appears that the unfortunate woman had been an inmate of the house only one month. Her deportment was ladylike, and she rented the apartments as a widow.

Gillett, of Hillsdale, Mich., as Pastor; Rev. B. T. Vincent, of Mauch Chunk, Penn., as Superintendent, and C.M. Nichols, of Springfield, Ohio, as Secretary. Over 1,000 persons were present.

William Cochran is a young man employed at the up-town branch office of THE TIMES. On Saturday evening, July 20, he was sent to the head office with a sachol contaning $285.

GRENADA, Miss., via PARIS, Ky., Aug. 19. Last nights was the most gloomy of all the nights in Grenada since the yellow fever broke out. No one can adequately set forth the distress of the living. About 75 whites are fenced up in the place, so tied to it by sympathy that they cannot leave, be their longing for life ever so strong. The whole country fears Grenada and shuns its infected inhabitants.

The body of Henry J. Montague arrived at the Erie Railway Depot, in Jersey City, at 7:15 o'clock yesterday morning, and was transferred from the custody of the express company to the hearse in waiting, under the supervision of the committee appointed to receive it, all of whom were present at the depot an hour before the arrival.

Cook, of the Second Precinct, of Staten Island, on the charge of arson.

WARREN, Ohio, Aug. 20. Gen. Garfield was renominated for Congress to-day in the old reunited Nineteenth District for the ninth one. Never before was there such complete harmony in the district, never such an expression of confidence in their representative. There is obsolutely not the semblance of opposition to him in the Republican ranks.

MEMPHIS, Aug. 20. The situation of affairs today is more favorable than at any time since the fever appeared. A marked decrease in the death-rate and number of new cases leads people to hope that the plague has been checked in its fatal course.

HARTFORD, Aug. 20. Everything was favorable for the opening day of the races at Charter Oak Park this afternoon. The weather was perfect, the track in excellent condition, and the attendance good. Both races were well trotted, and each was won in three straight heats.

The "Little Church Around the Corner" was nearly filled yesterday afternoon by members of the dramatic profession and others who assembled to assist at the funeral services of the late George Vining Bowers, the well-known actor.

JOHNSTOWN, N. Y., Aug. 20. The second days camp-meeting of the Albany and Saratoga Districts of the Troy Conference was held in the commodious grove near Northville, N. Y., this morning. The weather was fine. The morning traine from the south brought large numbers to the grove.

The Australian team of cricketers, at the invitation of Lord Londesborough, have arranged to play a match against the Gentlemen of England at Scarsborough, on Sept. 9 and 10, and they will also visit Doncaster to see the St. Leger run for. This will again alter their programme as given in THE TIMES a few days ago, and the trip to Boston and Canada will have to be left out.

The condition of John E. Leet, the insane Louisiana witness before the Potter Investigating Committee, had not materially changed yesterday. He had fewer violent outbreaks, but still labored under the delusion that he was surrounded by cutthroats and conspirators against his life.

WATER VALLEY, Miss., Aug. 20.--This is a place to which no unacclimated person ought to come in the middle of August, or at any other time of the year, for that matter. It is hardship enough to be compelled to spend a night here. The place is so flat and malaria laden that after sundown the fog can almost be cut with a knife.

BOSTON, Aug. 20. The hearing by the Attrrney-General in the case of Hiram H. Kimpton was begun this forenoon, and was not finished at the close of the day. Contrary to expectation, Kimpton was present, having been brought from Springfield by a couple of Sheriffs, and was himself heard, after counsel for both sides had made their opening arguments.

GRENADA, Miss, Aug. 20. The condition of affairs is slightly encouraging. The number of deaths during the past 24 hours has been reduced to eight, with seven new cases. The fever, however, is still unchecked. It is the opinion of the doctors that they will succeed in getting the disease under control by tomorrow; yet the weather is threatening ....
LONDON, Aug. 20.--A dispatch from Vienna to Reuter's Telegram Company announcces that after a severe engagement, the Austrians occupied Serajevo yesterday.

The application of Joseph M. Kochler, a retired banker, for his discharge from bankruptcy came before Register Ketchum yesterday, and there was opposition by several creditors. His liabilities amount to $400,000.
The funeral of the late Isaac C. Kendall, an old merchant of this City, took place yesterday from his late residence, No. 45 East Nineteenth-street.

A few days ago a man was discharged from the City Hospital, where for weeks he had been confined with a dangerous disease, and had been brought to death's door, but an iron constitution and indomitable will triumphed, and he now follows his daily routine, an apparently well man. His name is David J. Cole.

The signal success attending the first day's races of the sixth annual regatta of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen, rowed on the Passaic River at Neward yesterday afternoon, has rarely been equaled, and could not be exceeded.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 20. It may be safely assumed that 50,000 residents of this city are now absent. They have taken with them the wealth of the city, so that if the fever becomes intensified any further, as anticipated, the suffering will be very great.

Although we have received only a very brief and unsatisfactory summary of the nature of the project for a treaty of commerce with France, it would appear that it is one which has at least the merit of pleasing one party to the contract the French.

Capt. A.H. Bogardus, the champion marksman, who recently accomplished several remarkable feats in different parts of England, defeating the most noted of the English marksmen in matches for valuable prizes, arrived here last evening on the steam-ship Bothnia. His son Eugene, a lad of 13 years, who is also somewhat of an adept in the use of the shot-gun and rifle, accompanied him.

PANAMA, Aug. 12. The elections in the State of Santander, United States of Colombia, have resulted in favor of the Government of Gen. Trujillo. The election in the State of Cundinamarea is annouuced to take place at an early date.
SARATOGA, Aug. 21.--The conference of Administration of Hayes Republicans held here to-day comprised about 30 Republicans of more or less note, representing 20 counties.

Coroner Rouan's inquest over the remains of Police Officer Richard H. Smith, who was found murdered in his bed, on Pacific-avenue, Jersey City, on the morning of the 1st inst., was resumed at the court-house on Jersey City Heights, yesterday afternoon.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Aug. 21.--The Turkish commander at Batoum has informed the inhabitants that the Russians will enter that city on Aug. 27. The Municipal Government has announced that vessels will arrive to embark any of the inhabitants who do not wish to remain.
Mary McCue, aged 40, of No. 202 Moststreet, fell out of a fourth-story window at her residence at 4 o'clock yesterday morning, and was instantly killed.

The will of the late Thomas E. Cahill, of Philadelphia, disposed of property estimated to be worth at least $500,000. The Grand Lodge of Independent Order of Odd-fellows of the State of New-York reassembled yesterday morning in Chickering Hall. Grand Master Feniman presided. GRENADA, Miss., Aug. 21.--The situation is still growing worse, and to-night I am compelled to add a new list of horrors to the record. In the first place, there are 75 fresh cases of negroes down with the fever and about 15 deaths.

It looks as though Gen. BUTLER would overshoot his mask in aiming to become the Governor of Massachusetts, and to make the Executive Chair of that State the steppingstone to the candidacy of the National Party for President in 1880.

The moral remains of Henry J. Montague were laid to rest yesterday within the quiet precincts of Green-Wood Cemetery. No elaborate ceremonies were performed over the coffin, but a thousand mourners, many of them weeping attend the services in "The Little Church Around the Corner," and as many more followed the hearse to the cemetery. The funeral services were carried out in accordance with the programme previously arranged.

SARATOGA, Aug. 21.--The attendance to-day at the race-course was not as large as usual, although the programme was attractive and the track in good order. The racing was of a high order, however, and those who were present enjoyed a fine day's sport.

Mr. THURMAN has taken a leaf out of Mr. TILDEN'S book. he proposes to have his prospects for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1880 "worked up" by a select body of agents. A Washington dispatch says that letters are to be sent to leading Democrats in every Southern State requesting them to "work up" the Thurman fever in their respective neighborhoods.

Henry Armitt Brown, ene of the most promising young lawyers in Philadelphia a man to hear whom speak on political subjects the most conservative of Philadelphia's citizens would assemble by the thousand, died in that city yesterday afternoon, after an illness of more than two months. Mr. Brown was only 32 years old.

The arrest of William T. Van Zandt on the charge of burning a house at the junction of Castleton and Bard avenues, near Sailors' Snug Harbor, Staten Island, said to be owned by the wife of his brother, Leopold Van Zandt, was the principal topic of conversation yesterday along the north shore of the island.

Acquackanouk Township, Passaic County, is one of the oldest in New-Jersey, dating back to 1685, but it is not the wisest, or it would not be in its present trouble with its ex-counsel. Its taxable valuation is $1,581,300, and the taxes last year were about $25,000.

A marriage ceremony enveloped in an air of romantic mystery was performed in Taylor's Hotel Jersey City, at midnight of Tuesday. Shortly before midnight two handsomely-dressed gentlemen walked hurriedly into the First Precinct Police Station, on Gregory-street, and one of them, who described himself as Henry G. Harris, a lawyer, of Arch-street. Philadelphia, asked permission to go behind the Sergeant's desk to do some writing.

William Niblo, the veteran theatrical manager, died at his home, No. 10 East Twenty-fourthstreet, yesterday morning. He had reached the advanced age of 89 years. Mr. Niblo was in Irishman by birth, and was possessed of those qualities that win friends and cement friendship. He was jovial, kind-hearted, and generous almost to a faull.

Three steam-ships-the City of Brussels, of the Inman Line; the State of Virginia, of the State Line, and the Gellert, of the Hamburg-American Line--will sail for Europe to-day, and will carry out about 100 saloon passengers.

Gen. Sherman has not gone out into NewMexico, with the border troubles on his mind, but has sought novelty and the excitement of traveling as a distraction. Within the last six months Gen. Sherman has grown old very fast. The attempt to reduce the Army wore upon him more than one would suppose it would, but the crushing weight was the departure of his favorite son for a European monastery.

A sequel to the will of the late William H. Bernard, of No. 171 Remsen-street, Brooklyn, was developed yesterday by the opening of the mysterious tin box which, as heretofore announced, was on deposit in the vaults of the Long Island Safe Deposit Company.

Thomas Flynn, who was recently indicted for the murder of Martin Bernheim on June 1, was yesterday sent to the Lunatic Asylum by Judge Van Brunt, in Supreme Court, Chambers, the District Attorney consenting to this disposition of the case.

OCEAN GROVE, Aug. 21.--There was a marked increase in the attendance of worshipers at the camp-meeting to-day, 4,500 persons having arrived by special trains from the towns and villages in Southern, Western, and Central New-Jersey filling 90 cars of the Pennsylvania and Central New-Jersey Railroads.

WEST POINT, Aug. 21.--The officers and cadets in this Military Department were shocked this morning over the announcement that Cadet James Todd, Jr., had probably committed suicide. What led to the belief was the finding of three letters in his room at the hospital, one of three pages addressed to Dr. Irwin, another of 12 pages addressed "Mrs. Susan B. Todd, Indiana," who was his mother, and the other addressed to two of his classmates.

The Congressional Labor Committee, of which Mr. Abram S. Hewitt is Chairman, held its first session after a two weeks' vacation yesterday, in the Post Office building. Mr. Hewitt and Messrs. Rice and Thompson were the only members of the committee present, and but three witnesses were examined, although the session lasted for four hours without intermission.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 21.--Another of those extraordinary opinions for which Solicitor Raynor has become famous became known at the Treasury Department to-day. The facts of the case are these: Mr. A.R. Elder, of Oregon, formerly an Indian Agent, constituted I.L. Gibbs, a claim agent of this city, his attorney to prosecute some claims he had against the Government.

Capt. A. H. Bogardus, the champion wing shot of the world, called at the Clipper office yesterday morning, in accordance with an announcement previously published, but waited there in vain for the appearance of Dr. Carver, with whom he proposed to make an eight-hours match.

HARTFORD, Aug. 21.--The rain compelled a postponement of the races at Charter Oak Park this afternoon, after two heats in the 2:28 class and one in the 2:24 class had been trotted. The pacing race was not called.

It was 11 o'clock yesterday morning before the Potter Investigating Committee began its session, although the hour fixed for meeting was 10 o'clock, the delay being caused by the non-arrival of Major Burke, whose examination was not completed on Tuesday.
Register Little has received a voluntary petition in bankruptcy by S. Fry to get rid of old debts amounting to $13,000. He has no assets.

The sport was begun with a dash of one mile, purse $300, for all ages, entrance free, with weights 7 pounds below the scale; winners at this meeting of $500 to carry 3 pounds extra, and of $1,000 10 pounds; maidens of 3 years old allowed 3 pounds; of 4 years, 7 pounds, and of 5 years or upward, 12 pounds.

James Sinnot, a resident of Dutch Kills, em ployed as a pickman on Roxford's Steam Shovel, while at work yesterday afternoon at one of the screws, was crushed by the engine backing down or him, and died from his injuries in a few hours after.
RALEIGH, N.C., Aug. 22.--The Democratic Convention of this (the Fourth) district was held in this city to-day, and on the tenth ballot renominated Joseph J. Davis for a third term in Congress.

Gen. Butler did not arrive at the room occupied by the Potter Investigating Committee yesterday until nearly 1 o'clock, but the examination of Major Burke was carried on during his absence by Mr. Potter. Subsequently Mr.Stenger questioned the witness.

VIENNA, Aug. 22.--The news of the brilliant success at Serajevo has excited enthusiasm here. The efforts to stifle the insurrection speedily and completely will not be relaxed. The Austrians captured 27 cannon at Serajevo. Gen. Phillippovich has been promoted, and received the Grand Cross of the Order of Leopold.

A Correspondent of the St. Louis Globe-Democrat has come upon a couple of huntsmen down in Texas, one of whom he found exceedingly communicative upon the subject of alligators. They were returning, after a week's sport shooting such "prairie chickens" in the great plain bordering on Brazos River.

THE DISEASE SPREADING--FIFTY-ONE NEW CASES AND TEN DEATHS REPORTED YESTERDAY--AFFECTING INCIDENTS--THE DISEASE BELIEVED TO BE UNDER MEDICAL CONTROL--DEATHS OF REFUGEES AT HELENA, ARK., AND SENATORIA, MISS. MEMPHIS, Aug. 22.--We are in the midst of very little life and a great deal of death today in this deserted, plague-striken city.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22.--Subscription papers for the relief of the yellow fever sufferers were circulated in the departments to-day, and liberal contributions were received. Considerable sums of money have been transmitted from here by telegraph to the New-Orleans yellow fever sufferers, the telegrabh company charging nothing for the service.

Yesterday's session of the Hewitt Labor Investigating Committee attracted a much larger attendance than that of the day before, due probably to the announcement that Prof. William G. Sumner, of Yale College, was to be examined. Citizen Schwab and his fellows were absent.
The Floating Hospital of St. John's Guild conveyed 586 sick children on an excursion down the Bay yesterday. The delighted youngsters were treated to music and refreshments, and had a jolly time.
The undertaking establishment of Mr. John R. Newman, No. 170 Court-street, was entered by burglars on Wednesday night, and jewelry valued at $150 was stolen.

GRENADA, Miss., Aug. 22.--The brave and untiring Gen. W.J. Smith, Vice-President of the Howard Association, of Memphis, was stricken down with the fever to-day. He was our leader, and we have followed him by day and night since this fearful seourge began.

NASHVILLE, Aug. 22.--There are two mild cases of yellow fever here, though only a few persons are aware of the fact. It is feared that a panic would ensue if the public were informed at the present time, when the news from the infected cities is so discouraging.
BOSTON, Aug. 22.--The hearing in the Kimpton case was concluded to-day with Attorney-General Youmans' argument, and the case was taken under consideration.

HARTFORD, Aug. 22.--The unfinished races in the 2:28 and 2:24 classes, postponed from yesterday, were called at 11 o'clock to-day. There was a good attendance and the track was in good condition. It being reported that some of the horses in the 2:24 race were held back, the judges, to-day, before the...

WASHINGTON, Aug. 22,--The receipts from internal revenue collections for the month of July last, the first month of the fiscal year, were nearly $1,000,000 in excess of the amount collected in July, 1877, and gave every indication of continued prosperity.

YANKTON, Dakota Territory, Aug. 21.-- H.C. Dear, who arrived from the Spotted Tail Agency early yesterday morning, says that just previous to his departure a half-breed came in from the moving Indians, who were then 125 miles out, and reported that serious trouble had broken out among them, and they had commenced exchanging shots.

The manager of the Newark Orphan Asylum have instituted proceedings, both in the criminal and in the civil courts, against Mrs. James H. Woodward, of Roselle, for alleged inhuman treatment of a boy who had been an inmate of that institution.
"Olivia" still attracts large audiences at the Union-Square Theatre.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 22.--Ex-Gov. Thomas L. Young was to-day nominated for Congress by the Republicans of the Second Ohio District. He is a man of great personal popularity, and has never yet been defeated for public office.

The suburb of Philadelphia known as Germantown will soon be gaining a reputation for the mysterious disappearance of its children, if the thing is allowed to go on. PEACH-STAINS.--I believe the only thing that will remove peach-stains from white goods is Java water. Get, say, 10 cents' worth, lay your garment on a crockery plate or dish and pour the Java water on it. You must watch it, for it only takes a few minutes to draw the stain out. Wash out immediately in clean water, for if it stands too long it will injure the goods.--KATE.

You will find, if you carefully examine a bird's wing, that all the bones and muscles are placed along the front edge, which is thus made very stiff and strong. The quill feathers are fastened in such a way that they point backward, so that the hind edge of the wing is not stiff like the front edge, but is flexible and bends at the least touch.

JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 24.--Not a case of yellow fever has yet appeared in Jackson, and the authorities are working with the energy of despair to keep it out. A simple squib by itself is an interesting and attractive fire-work, but in the presence of that complex pyrotechnical arrangement called a "Jack-in-the-box" it sinks into insignificance; its brilliant coruscations are unnoticed, the bang with which its existence terminates causes no shock, and the very odor it leaves behind is attributed to its powerful rival.

CINCINNATI, AUG. 28.--At the close of the session of the Chamber of Commerce this noon, Secretary Sherman was introduced to the merchants by President Hartwell, and was greeted with cheers. He responded as follows:
The attaches of Station H of the Postal Department, will have a Summer night's, reception at Terrace Garden, Fifty-eighth-street, near Third-ave-. nue, this evening.
The Paterson Cricket Club plays its first match of this season to-day, when a term from the Manhattan Club will meet them at Halidon, Paterson.
VICKSBURG, Aug. 28.--The death list during the past 24 hours shows a marked decrease. This is a hopeful sign, but as a cool, damp night is setting in, I fear it will prove delusive.

That which singularly contributes to the pacific aspect of Paris at the present moment is the marked absence of soldiers from the streets. Englishmen who are habitually resident here may not be struck by the change which, from a military point of view, has come over the French capital.

MEMPHIS, Aug. 28.--The first item of note that attracted your reporter's attention this morning was the following extract from the report of Dr. R.W. Mitchell to the Howard Association: "I need 10 more physicians. ...

Daniel Gillen assigned his property for the benefit of creditors to John Ryan yesterday. Isaac L. Sagrier, of Saugertios, has gone into voluntary bankrrptcy in this City to get rid of debts to the amount of $14,000. He has no assets.
"It's no disgrace to be poor, but it is mighty inconvenient," said Senators McDONALD, of Indiana, the other day. Of course, if Senator McDONALD said that, he meant it as a Democratic committee man.

Paul G. Schmidt's suit for an absolute divorce from his wife Emma A. Schmidt, which was recently brought before Judge J.F. Daly, in the Common Pleas, has some peculiar features. The parties to the action were married on Sept. 15, 1874, and have one child.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Aug. 28.--Serious trouble between the authorities of towns in Ulster and Delaware Counties and the Ulster and Delaware and Wallkill Valley Railroad conpanies is threatened, owing to difficulties in regard to the levying of taxes on the latter.

The steamer Bothnia, of the Cunard Line, which sailed for Liverpool yesterday, carried out 97 cabin passengers, among whom were Sir Henry and Lady Scholfield, Mr. George Jones, Francis Pym, Rev. and Mrs. W.H. Williams, Henry Seligman, Dr. L. Madan, Dr. Donald Kennedy, and Dr. A.R. Blair. To-day the steam-ships Battle, of the White Star ...

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28.--Orders from the Navy Department have been sent to Acapulco, Mexico, directing tho steamer Tuscarora to return to San Francisco. Lieut. F.G. Paine is ordered to the Powhatan, at New-York, and Mitdshipman Charles H. Gove is detached from the Plymouth and ordered ...
LIVERPOOL, Aug. 28.--A meeting was held at the Town Hall to-day for the relief of the sufferers from yellow fever is the Gulf States of America. It was attended by many influential citizens.

The dealers in counterfeit money in NewYork were unfortunate yesterday, no less than siz of them having fallen into the clutches of the law. Four of the prisoners are prominent individuals in their business.
The following facts relating to our foreign commerce are given in a letter to Hon. John B. Hawley, Acting Secretary of the Treasury, by Joseph Nimmo, Jr., Acting Chief of the Bureau of Statistics:

BOSTON, Aug. 28.--The most influential of the Butler Democrats were absent from the meeting of the Democratic State Committee to-day, and those present, including Edward Avery, Leverett Saltonstall, George W. Gill, of ...

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug.28.--A dispatch from Canton, Miss., says: "Send us two nurses immediately; fever increasing." The Times' correspondent at Canton, writing under date of the 27th, says: "I arrived here Sunday last. ` Pretty tough times. Not a single business ...

SARATOGA, Aug. 28.--The coming politcal campaign is evidently exciting a great deal of interest among the politicians, if not among the people at large. So much preliminary skirmishing among party leaders has seldom been seen, especially in what is called an "off" year in politics.

HARTFORD, Aug. 28.--There wore two closely contested trotting matches at Plainville Park today. In the 2:25 class Driver was the favorite in the pools. Wizz was the favorite in the 2:35 class. John H. Starin had the pole in the 2:35 race, but ...

The great Chinese Encyclopedia recently purchased for the British Museum certainly ought to be a bargain. We cannot do for it as Macaulay once did for somebody's book--give its dimensions and its weight avordupois--but 5,020 volumes for $1,500 certainly looks cheap. It no doubt would have been a good deal dearer but for the peculiar circumstances under which it was purchased.

The House of of Bishops of the Protestant Episcopal Church was to have held a special session yesterday, at Grace chapel, for the transaction of general business, but in consequence of the absence of a quorum, the deliberations of the body were adjourned, after a brief debate, until 10 o'clock this morning. The Bishops began assembling at the chapel at 11 A.M., and at noon, when a private ...
