An attempt to smuggle 18 pieces of costly hand-made lace was discovered yesterday morning by a Customs officer on board the Cunard steamer Algeria. The Custom-house refused to divulge the facts in the case, but hints were given in a mysterious manner that ...

Judge VAN Brunt, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday ordered the discharge of James Watson, alias Big Jim, who was accused, jointly with William Hart, of committing a burglary at the residence of william Palmer. Hart was remanded.

TORONTO, Aug.28.--The Globe to-day prints the following dispatch from London: The Times founds an editorial on an altogether trustworthy communication from its Philadelphia correspondent that Americans desire to renew negotiations for a reciprocity treaty with Canada.

One hundred years ago to-day the soil of Newport was stained by the blood of patriots spilled while fighting the soldiers of King GEORGE. The stirring scenes which occured Aug. 29, 1778, are among the most heroic ...

Selina Wadge was executed yesterday morning, at Bodmin Jail, for the murder of her child, at Launceston, on the 21st of July last. The representatives of the press being refused admission to the prison, some difficulty was experienced in obtain ing any reliable information of the circumstances attending the execution, but the scene appears to have been an unusually painful one, all the officers, ...

HARTFORD, Aug. 28.--The State Temperance Convention at Saybrook, to-day, nominated a State ticket, as follows: For Governor, Jesse G. Baldwin, of Middletown; for Lieutenant-Governor, George P. Rogers, Jr., of NewLondon; for Secretary of State, A.S. Beardsley, of Plymouth; for Treasurer, W.S. Williams, of Glastonbury, and Edmund Tuttle, of Meriden.

A dastardly attempt at arson was brought to light yesterday morning. The man who is charged with the crime is one Henry Budgistiefsky, a saloonkeeper at No. 98 Ridge-street, which is a four-story brick building.

James McDonald, first mate of the German bark Midas, who is charged with having assaulted some of his men as described in yesterday's TIMES, was arraigned before Justice Wandell yesterday, in the Tombs Police Court.

The national flag hung limp down the front of the Opera-house in Elizabeth yesterday. The State Convention of Greenbackers met in the public hall up stairs. Every reference made by the members to the name of Denis Kearney elicited stormy applause.
LONDON, Aug. 28.--The British brig Tabor Capt. Bache, from St. John, New-Brunswick, July 24, for St. Nazaire, arrived at Queenstown to-day, water-logged.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 28.--The situation to-night is critical. The fever seems to have established itself in every quarter of the city. One square, bounded by St. Charles, Euterpe, Carondelet, and Potyminia streets, ...

WASHINGTON, Aug. 28.--Collector Woodcock, of the Nashville District, has been waging such a vigorous warfare against the illicit distillers that many of them are already making overtures to United State Commissioner Mather ...

The second annual regatta of the Metropolitan Association of Amateur Oarsmen, rowed yesterday afternoon on the Hudson off Pleasant Valley, was not a decided success, although there were several interesting and hotly-contested races.
LONDON, Aug. 28.--The following is the text of the Russian imperial ukase issued at St. Petersburg temporarily remitting crimes against the State and attacks upon officials to courtmartial:

The four Men captured by Inspector Murray last evening, in the saloon No. 357 West Fortyseventh-street, on a charge of being concerned in the masked burglary at Fairview, N.J., were taken before Justice Wanddell, in the Tombs Police Court, yesterday morning, and remanded until this morning.

PARIS, Aug. 28.--At the session of the Internatinal Monetary Conference to-day Gov. Fenton closod the general debate on the part of the United States. He summarized the previous arguments of the American delegates, and answered the objections to them.
The latest statement of the liabilities and assets of the Treasury does not show that very rapid progress has been made in getting the dollar of the fathers into the pockets of their descendants.

For the past eight years there has been a contention among the stockholders of the Quicksilver Mining Company. On Feb. 24, 1870, the company amended its by-laws and adopted resolutions authorizing the issuance of preferred stock.

The Congressional Labor Comittee got to work promptly at 11 o'clock yesterday, and continued in session for nearly six hours. Mr. Hewitt announced that Mr.Rice had been called home by businesa engagements, leaving only the Chairman and Mr. Thompson to examine the witnesses.

The journals which have been retained in the interest of mismanaged life insurance companies, and have abused THE TIMES for having proved, on the authority of the companies themselves, that their mismanagement is bearing its natural consequences, must now level their batteries at the Insurance Superintendents.

The members of the Chamber of Commerce Relief Committee are working zealously for the benefit of the sick in the South, and their labors are meeting with remarkable success. Since Monday morning last they have collected $25,604.71, and they expect to obtain at least $50,000 for the assistance of the distressed.

There was a somewhat singular scene at the milk depot of the Harlem Railroad, Forty-seventhstreet and Lexington-avenue, yesterday morning, when 14 milk cars, each containing about 150 milkcans, moved into the half-lighted building.

The second competition for the "Gildersleeve" badge took place at Creedmoor yesterday afternoon. The weather was pleasant, and members of tha National Guard who were interested in rifle shooting turned out in large numbers.

SARATOGA, Aug. 28.--The third day of the extra series of races furnished ample amusement for the patrons of the turf, but the crowds are departing, and many of the horses have gone away to recruit for the Fall campaign, so that the attendance of spectators has fallen off and the fields are not as large as usual.

SARATOGA, Aug. 29.--The paper manufacturers took their time about assembling this morning, and it was 10:45 o'clock before the meeting was called to order. Fault having been found with the acoustic properties of the Opera-house, the convention sat to-day in the reading-room of the Grand Union Hotel.

THE TIMES has received $2 from Robert Lee Monell for the Children's Sea-side Sanitarium. "F.A.M." is informed that the $5 subscription to the yellow fever fund was acknowledged in THE TIMES of Sunday last.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29.--Complaints have been made to the Treasury Department that the banks are embarrassed by the scarcity of small bills, and this scarcity is attributed to a supposed policy on the part of the Treasury Department to retire the one and two dollar notes in order to make a place for the subsidiary silver, and for the new silver dollars.

CONSTANTINOPLE, Aug. 29.--It is considered probable that the mediation of the powers will result in the cession to Greece of much smaller territory than she asked for. It has been agreed that Batoum shall be surrendered on the 6th of September, with which the Russians seem satisfied.

NALISTS TO THE FEET OF THE POPE STOCKHOLM, Aug. 29.--The International Prison Congress for the Prevention and Suppression of Crime, including penal and reform atory treatment, which assembled here on the 21st inst., has adjourned. The next meeting will probably be in Rome in accordance with a special reauest of Italy.

The newspapers continue to print Mayor ELY'S juvenile poetry. It is time that this thing should stop. Not that the poetry is not good enough, as good as the average, but its publication at this crisis is evidently made with malevolent intent. Up to Mr. ELY's appearance as a Representative in Congress from one of the districts of this City he had preserved a fair reputation as a leather-dealer ...

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29.--Another circular has been issued to the creditors of the Jay Cooke estate by the Trustee, Edwin M. Lewis, in which notice is given of another cash dividend of 5 per cent., which will probably be paid on or before the 1st of October next.

TRENTON, Aug. 29.--The body of Arthur Brandt, book-keeper for Fisher Norris' anvil factory, in this city, was found early this morning with a bullet-hole in the right side of the forehead, about a mile from this city, near Atterbury's Woods. A small revolver lay loosely in the right hand, and there were scratches on the neck. No money or watch was found on his person.

Charles Link, alias Fink, who has been in the Tombs since June 3 on a charge of conspiracy, was discharged by Judge Van Brunt yesterday, because two terms of the Court of General Sessions have been held since his incarceration and he has not been brought to trial.

The national bankrupt act of 1867 expires with the present week and will leave an accumulation of business in the hands of Registers, Assignees, and courts which it will take them months to dispose of. Ever since the act of repeal was passed, and indeed from the time the matter began to be agitated in April last, there has been a ...

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 29.--At the meeting of the Board of Health to-night the origin of the epidemic was discussed, and from the data furnished it was plausibly argued that it could be traced to the ship Souder. Dr. Choppin gave in full the result of his experiment with the ice-water spray.

The tenth annual regatta for North Shrewsbury Rivor yachts was sailed off Fair Haven yesterday, and, but for the lack of a breeze, would have proved a highly-interesting event. But the breeze-- light from the south-east at the start--gradually died away, until several of the yachts were left, becalmed, far from the finish when darkness closed tho day's sport.

PARIS, Aug. 29.--The French committee on the France-American commercial treaty gave a banquet to the American delegates at the Grand Hotel to-night. About 200 guests were present, including the American and French delegates at the recent conference. M. Teisserenc De Bort, Minister of Agriculture; the Under Secretary of the Department of Public Works, ...

SARATOGA, Aug. 29.--The Republican conference met at 11 o'clock this morning in the ball-room of the United States Hotel. The attendance numbered about 100, and every county in the State was represented.

A terrible stabbing affray occurred at 10 o'clock last night in the slaughter-house of Swartzchild Sulzberger, in East Forty-fifthstreet, between First-avenue and Avenue A. The parties to the affray were Louis Kress, aged 40, of No. 880 First-avenue, and Joseph Ottna, aged 45, of No. 853 First-avenue. The conflict resulted in Ottna being stabbed six times and dangerously injured.

George Groencke assigned his property for the benefit of creditors to Richard L. Plahn yesterday. George W. Springsted, builder, has applied for relief in bankruptcy, having debts to the amount of $5,800, and nominal assets.

The examination into the case of Henry Bugishofsky, charged with setting fire to his saloon at No. 98 Ridge-street, on Tuesday night last, was continued before Justice Otterbourg, in the Essex Market Police Court, yesterday morning, and occupied nearly the ontire day. After the Deputy Fire Marshal, members of the Fire Department, and others, had been examined, the accused was placed on the stand, and told a seemingly straightforward story.
The Grand Duke Alexis arrived in Paris on the 16th. The King and Queen of Denmark and the Princess Thyra arrived in England on a visit on the 16th inst.

A disastrous fire, involving a loss of $150,000 worth of proporty, in Harrison, East Newark, N.J., occurred yesterday morning. The works of the Peters Manufactnring Company, for the manufacture of table, enameled, and stair cloth, were large building on the block bounded by Sussex, Fifth, Bergen and Fourth streets. The Morris and Essex Railroad runs just south of the factory site, not more than a block distant.

The horse ridden by Officer McArthur, of the mounted Squad, fell yesterday while its rider was trying to stop a runaway team in Cumberland street, and the officer, falling on the pavement, was serriously injured on the head. He was taken home.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29.--The relief work in Chicago for the yellow fever sufferers goes bravely on. Up to date the Citizens' General Committee has collected $6,872.10, and $5,131.11 has been received by the Mayor, the Young Men's Christian Association, Congressman Harrison, and others, making the total amount actually received up to date $12,003.21.

The meeting of the Relief Committee of the Chamber of Commerce, which was held yesterday at noon, was attended by a number of gentlemen who have become interested in obtaining assistance for the sick and starving people of those districts of the South in which the yellow fever is prevalent.

Last evening Miss Mary Anderson made her reappearance upon the New-York stage after an absence of several months, during which, it was readily presumed, she had seriously cultivated the crude, though remarkable, qualities of her talent. She has visited Europe, and she has enjoyed the privilege of witnessing Bernhardt and the other artists of the Comedie Francaise.

The ninth annual regatta of the Gramercy Boat Club was held on the Harlem River yesterday afternoon, and, so far as the races are concerned, was a success. The management was not a suc cess. An unsuitable steamer called the Blackbird, manned by a surly crew and managed by an unlucky pilot, was furnished for the use of the spectators, who numbered about 250 persons.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29.--Kearney's visits to the departments were evidently designed to magnify his own importance. The visit which was least acceptable to him was, perhaps, that at the Treasury Department, where he paid his respects to Acting Secretary of the Treasury Hawley.

Of all the various brass instruments which have been devised by musical or malevolent ingenuity, there is none which in its capacity for inflicting both torture and delight is comparable to the trombone. Those who have heard the trombone only when played by a master never fail to be surprised at its unique beauty of tone and its wonderful singing powers. It so happens that a true trombone virtuoso is a rarity.

It is rare that such a tremendous crowd is seen as that which assembled within and about the Hotel Brighton, Coney Island, last night, to have a glimpso of the great display of fire-works advertised as one of the attractions of the occasion. It wns the judgment of those experienced in such mutters that searcely less than 50,000 people came and went a way in the course of the evening.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., Aug. 29.--The Democratic Congressional Convention of this district held three or four sessions to-day without accomplishing anything. To-night, the credentials of the delegates being agreed upon, Messrs. Neale and Menifee were withdrawn, and Mr. Hunton nominated by acclamation. Mr. Neale was invited to the convention, and spoke in advocacy of Hunton's election.

The President's application to Congress for an appropriation of the $5,500,000 called for by the fisheries' award was made conditional upon a purpose of the State Department to reopen correspondence with the British Government. Mr. EVARTS' accompanying memorandum indicated certain grounds upon which the award might be ...

What is most intere3 in his con tribution is the evident purpose to convey in a delicate and inoffensive way a lesson re garding the superior strength and stability of the British monarchy-which is practi cally for the citizen as fr eo as a Re public-and the inherent weaknesses of our nominally more Democratic. system. This superiority, or assumed superiority, is made to appear particularly in t.'oe secure con of sect the guarded elevation of position of the nominal executive Lead oP the nation, the immediate responsibility to the people s representatives of tlio istry, or actual depository of the executive functions, and the direct operation at all times oP the public sentiment upon govern ment. through the lack of any fixed term of existence for the Ad ministration or Parliament. TLe onces liere suggested are in some respects radical nod even vital to the farce of government. A permanent and tary Presidency would nut fu princi ple from monarchy, and it may be doubted whether it could, in a country like , be surrounded witli the guaran tees that exist fu 3, which at once sustain the authority and dignity of the crown and deprive it of all personal power. On the other hand, a Presidential term of indefinite or undefined duration would be au invitation to political anarchy and excitement, than tlio periodical disturbance of a Presidential election. With us the President is prac tically tlio head of the Cabinet; Lo is chosen to perform certain duties, and implies power and responsibil ity, to be used in some cases according to lils own discretion, our theory assumes that it is safer to 3 that discretion with a person chosen by the people to exercise it than to hove it evolved fu secret coun cils or diffused at largo in the public senti ment oP tlio notion. The President, with this power and discretion placed in his hands by the people for a term of years, must of necessity coun and have their tenure dependent upon the working of the admin istration.

The now , as it is sometimes, very unjustly, called, is substan tially the philosophy of ScuorEW taueR and his , . 3 of the Germans who liad accepted , \G, , Or have gone over to .7Cttot'E\HdC'ER, who totally uis with and despised those teachers. Bettvaen the two pessimists there is little ; stand to one as master and disciple, and are entirely liar iu the belief that life, even at best, I is not worth living; consciousness and thought are the source of , and that, , the higher our develop--' meat, tlio larger our culture, the unhappier cue must be. Our solo hope, as Lhey would put it, is in the absence of hope; our solo reward in existence depends on getting rid of existence. H. .w's is tlio Unconscious, is Annihila tion. Tlio latter regards this world not only as the worst world has ever been, but the worst world could or can be. It is not enough, according to , to cease to live; it is our duty to the desire for life. When is perfected, ,it will b3 obliterated by its own will, an.l the purpose of the Unconscious bu achieved. It is ble that ScuorEwacER's writing.., attracted scarcely any while lie lived-ho has been dead but eighteen years-are now rend and in Germany. Tlte doctrine of negation, the philosophy of despair, has coma to the front, has grown into sudden favor with the intel lectual.

At an early hour yesterday morning the Fountain House, at Waukesha, Wis., was destroyed. It was a three-story brick structure, owned by Matthew Latin, of Chicago, and was one of the most popular hotels in Wisconsin. The total loss is $30,000, with insurance of $50,000 on building and $25,000 on furniture. All of the 400 guests escaped, with most of their baggage.

Diamond digging is expensive. We will take, for example, the average digger, who owns a quarter of a claim and works his own ground. VIENNA, Aug. 31.--The Presse says the conclusion of an Anglo-Turkish convention has become altogether doubtful. The order to intern Hafiz Pasha has been countermanded, though his allotted residence was already engaged. He has started for Constantinople.

Warden Finn, of the Tombs, had a strange visitor yesterday in the person of a young lad, aged 17, who said he desired to see his brother. The boy's face was much sun-burned, his clothes were seedy, and he looked as if he had traveled a long distance on foot.

--Much has been said in dis paragement of the climate of the island. This climate, however, is no worse than that of other islands in the Mediterranean. Spring, and more especially April, is a delightful season to travel in, and the heat of Summer is tempered by refreshing sea-breezes.

M. Granier de Cassagnac, father of the belligerent editor of Le Pays, and himself a prominent journalist in the past, is contributing his recollections of the Second Empire to the Paris Figaro. In these he is making some interesting revelations regarding Victor Hugo in his younger days.

A report which has just been published by Mr. Victor Drummond, on the question of actual or threatened American competition with English industry, gives, in a very interesting form, the impressions of an intelligent official who has no personnl concern in the matter, but views all the facts as an unprejudiced man of the world.

The clerks in Register Winslow's office, in Brooklyn, were kept busy all day yesterday, a large number of persons availing themselves of the last opportunity offered them for filling petitions in bankruptcy. NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 31.--The total number of cases reported to the Howards during the 24 hours ending at 9 this evening is 275. In the opinion of the visiting physicians the malignity is abating day by day. In the past four days there have been over 1,000 cases, with only 213 deaths, the epidemic being now spread throughout the city.

Matching of colors by ordinary artificial light has been a difficult and an uncertain process. Reimann's Farber Zeitung strongly recommends the use of tho electric light, however, in dye-works, as it permits colors to be compared as accurately as by daylight.

Mr. E. Trott, agent of the Children's Aid Society of New-York City, arrived at Charlottesville on Wednesday morning at 11:35 A.M. with a company of 15 boys, for whom homes had been provided in this county.

Mr. Flood, the millionaire, has become possessed of half a block of ground on Cushman-street, between Mason and Taylor, extending from California to Sacramento street, which comprises a bold and commanding site for a palatial residence. The fact that many buildings have been recently removed therefrom has encouraged the impression that he is preparing to erect a home there that shall far outshine any architectural attempt of the kind yet made in this city.

A new mineral has been sent to the British Museum by Mr. Barnett, of Chyandor, near Pen zance. Prof. N.S. Maskelyne calls it Liskeardite, and gives a preliminary description of it. The color is blue or greenish blue, and the structure fibrous. It is associated with earthy chlorite and quartz. Iron pyrites, some copper pyrites, and mispickel are disseminated in the lode material.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 1.--Agreeably to the foreshadowing of the past three days, the death-roll has again doubled. The official report embraces 88 deaths up to 12 M., but falls 15 short of what it should be, as three physicians made report of that number additional five minutes after the hour. It may be therefore considered that 103 deaths have occurred up to 12 to-day.
Midhat Pasha has been traveling in Scotland. Mr. Gladstone is to deliver his address as Lord Rector of the University of Glasgow in the second week of November.

Conner made complaint before Justice Lever, of Flushing, on Thursday, that he had been robbed of $55 while in a drunken sleep in an outhouse at John Halleran's place on Broadway, and a warrant was issued for the arrest of Thomas Brennan, Thomas Bulger, and Joseph Maher, on suspicion. It is during the hot weather that the weakness of the human shirt-sleeve is most conspicuously shown. The wristband droops over the wrist, becomes moist and limp, and maddens the wearer as he vainly tries to induce it to retire to the seclusion of its true home in the coat-sleeve.

The great American-German festival of the rear, the Volksfest of the Plattdeutsche Verein, that is to last four days, was opened yesterday at the Schuetzen Park, on Union Hill, near Hoboken. This festival is an outgrowth of that kindly German feeling that prompts periodical gatherings for mutual intercourse, the renewal of old friendships, and the formation of new ones, of those emigrants or their descendants who claim a common fatherland and steak the same tongue.

The eagerness of inventors and chemists to discover new and more powerful explosives than any previously known continues unabated. And though many of the fresh substances never realize the claims put forward on their behalf, they are constantly succeeded by others equally pretentious. Thus we now hear of a new explosive material called tonite, or cotton-powder, which is stated to possess peculiar properties.

So Mrs. Stevens, the mother of Mrs. Arthur Paget, is about to console herself for the loss she has sustained through the marriage of her daughter by taking unto herself a husband. There seems to be a demand upon the American widow market just now.

Mr. Thoms, the celebrated writer on longevity, writes thus to the Pall Mall Gazette: "The Morgans are evidently a long-lived family. In the hundreds, I believe I might say thousands, of letters which I have received on the subject of reputed centenarians, I have, I believe, several respecting 'Morgans' who claim to have outlived the century, besides Catherine Morgan, who died in the neighborhood of Merthyr Tydfil on Feb. 23, 1794, aged 106.!

The star paper of the new North American Review is that by the late Premier of England, and it would be the most noticeable contribution in any case, even supposing the subject Mr. Gladstone had chosen were without interest to Americans and the method of treating it dull.
The Alabama Greenbackers hold a conference in Birmingham to-day. The Arkansas election of State officers and Legislature occurs to-day.

As Sergt Michael Rooney, of the Seventeenth Precinct, was riding home from the station-house for supper about 6:30 o'clock last evening, he noticed, as he left an Avenue B car at Thirty-fourth-street, an immense crowd of people at Thirty-eighth and Thirty-ninth streets and First-avenue. The street was packed, with the multitude, and they seemed to be agitated by some great excitement. The Sergeant hurried forward

Julius Hildebrand was found dead in a small room at No. 20 First street yesterday morning. He was apparently about 40 years of age. The room in which he died was formerly a closet, and was but six feet square. When Coroner Woltman received notice of the case he went to the place with Deputy Coroner Cushman. The room was found to be without windows, and lighted only by a very poor skylight.

Last night at 7 o'clock an ugly little tug-boat lay rocking off the Quarantine dock, about a mile below Vanderbilt landing. Health Officer Vanderpoel and his deputy descended into the cabin and made a cursory examination of the case of Mrs. Joseph Celli, from No. 10 Union-court, University-place, who had been brought down to Quarantine upon an air-bed.

The air of surprise with which the development of the Greenback doctrine in the Southern States is received indicates a curious disregard of the drift of Southern opinion and of the causes that have everywhere contributed to the growth of the Greenbackers' organization.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 2. A nervous apprehension now fills the city. Not over onehalf of its domain has been invaded by the fever, and yet the figures are swelling to formidable proportions. Lavish contributions are pouring in from all sides, and every nerve is strained to the utmost in the alleviation of suffering.

A meeting of the Board of Trustees of the East River Bridge was held yesterday afternoon, and Hon. Henry C. Murphy presided. The Secretary road a statement of the receipts and expenditures during the month of August, showing that the amount of money received from all sources was $146,667 56, and the amount expended $115,293 88. The total receipts to date have been $9,835,894 48, and the expenditures $9,833,988,44.

A Western paper suggests Denis Kearney for Minister to China when Butler becomes President.
MEMPHIS, Sept. 2. A special to the Appeal from Holly Springs, Miss., announces 50 cases there, and a panic among the citizens.

The Eighth Regiment finished its class rifle practice for the season at Creedmoor yesterday. There were 130 men and officers present, under command of Lient.Col. F. A. Schilline. Capt. Edward Barber, Regimental Inspector of Rifle Practice, superintended the firing.

Americans, as a rule, do not take to family seats, as this term is understood in Eugland and in some other countries. When they do, or when some American cherishes the vain delusion that he may found a home for successive generations of his deseendants, it seems as if fate revenged herself by denying him a lineal posterity able and willing to maintain the state designed for them.

The wagons that carry the last editions of the afternoon papers to the upper parts of the City go at such breakneck speed that almost everybody has learned to keep out of their way. Each paper has its wagon, the Dapers are alt ready about the same time, and it is a grand race to Harlem, packages being thrown ont, here and there, along the way.

There are in all countries a large number of utterly unscrupulous politicians, some of whom are always willing to join any formidable faction that will accept their leadership, and thereby give them a power they can use, a notoriety which gratifies their vanity, and an influence which, in the last resort, they can always sell.
The Board of Alderman meet to-day for the first time in a fortnight. BROOKLY.

There were two novelties which attracted an excellent audience to Booth's Theatre last evening, namely: the first production in this City of Mr. Wills' drama "Jane Shore" and the first appearance upon the Metropolitan stage, in her capacity of tragic actress, of Miss Gonevieve Ward.

PETERSBURG, Va., Sept. 2. The most destructive fire that has occurred here for years started between 12 and 1 o'clock this morning , and is believed to have been the work of an incendiary. It broke out in the large grocery store of Daniel Rahily, on Sycamore-street, which was destroyed.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 2.--A lively sensation was yesterday created in the usually quiet suburb of Roxborough, about four miles from this city, by the announcement that there had been an elopement from the Dodge mansion in that place of young Anson Dodge, aged 19, and his cousin, Ida Dodge, a dashing young miss of 16 years.

A meeting of the Board of Health was held last evening, Dr. Choppin in the chair. After the transaction of some business, Dr. Loeber was called to the chair, and Dr. Choppin took the floor. He said in substance, that as the members of the board well knew, we had an epidemic in our midst. In his opinion the disease had been imported.

A singular suicide was committed yesterday morning at an early hour in the cottage of Mr. A. Lane" One Hundred and Sixty-fourth-street and Grove avenue, Melrose. For some nine months past a young Englishman named Henry J. Heath had been boarding at this cottage, which is a neat three-story wooden structure. A cistern is dust beneath the window of the bedroom Heath occupied.

BLACK lays down a doctrine that is fortified by judicial decisions of the highest authority.

Gov. Seymour has written the following letter in regard to the Herkimer monument: UTICA, Aug. 26, 1878. DEAR SIR: Theodore Faxton, Esq., called on me this morning about the Herkimer monument. He says he will give $200 toward its construction if enough is raised to put up a monument which can be seen from the railroad on the north side of the Mohawk River.

About 3,000 persons gathered in Military Park, Newark, last evening, to hear the "sand-lots orator," Denis Kearney. He was introduced by Mr. Beecher, a local Greenback politician, and began his speech by a violent outpouring of abuse upon the press generally, and that of Newark particularly.

On Thursday we printed, in good faith, a circular purporting to emanate from Mr. James Buell, Secretary of the American Bankers' Association. We found it in the columns of the Springfield Republican, which likewise printed it in Rood faith, and, like ourselves, commented severely upon it.

BOSTON, Sept. 2. A lad, 12 years old, stabbed his brother, 15 years old, in a quarrel this afternoon over a rabbit-box, the ownership of which both claimed. The culprit fled after the deed, and was arrested only after a four hours' search by the Police.

One week's exprience with the elevated railway on Third-avenue has served to convince the business and professional men along that thoroughfare that prophecies are not always fulfilled. It was prophesied, for instance, by competent engineers that the noise would be very trifling.

The Local Inspectors of steam vessels, Messrs. Jayne and Matthews,began an Inquiry yesterday into the causes which led to the collision on Aug. 13 in the East River between the Boston Line steamer Providence and a scow in tow of the tug-boat Chief, by which four lives were lost. The accident took place between and 7 o'clock in the morning.

Denis Kearney, the champion of the working man, received his Jersey City friends in a vacant lot on the north-west corner of Hamilton Park, Jersey City, last evening. A rude platform had been constructed, and four gaunt poles towered from each corner.
The Nationalists of Tioga, County have made nominations for local officers, and are running Samuel Ellison for member of Assembly.

Samuel Allen McCoskry, Bishop of the Diocese of Michigan, was last evening solemnly deposed from the Ministry of the Protestant Episcopal Church by the unanimous action of the House of Bishops, assembled at Grace Chapel. This action was a surprise to all save the members of the House, it having been generally understood that the resignation of Bishop McCoskry, submitted immediately...

A most exciting scene occurred at the fashionable boarding-house, No. 14 East Thirty-firststreet, at 9:30 o'clock last night, during the arrest of a rebel Captain for an alleged attempt to shoot a rival in the house at midnight the night before. The history of the affair is a most curious and dramatic one. No. 14 East Thirty-firststreet is a large brown-stone structure, with a high stoop.

Between 12 and 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon James Connors and a companion whose name is said to be Connolly, entered the grocery and liquor store of Frederick Meyer, corner of East New-York and Brooklyn avenues, in the town of Flatbush, and asked for drinks.

A young man residing in Hazleton, Penn., recently lost his eye under very peculiar circumstances. He was removing his shirt when the point of the spiral wire attached to a rudimentary stud pierced his eye and destroyed its usefulness. This traged naturally attracts attention to the characteristics of the modern shirt, and render an inquiry into its origin peculiarly appropriate.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3. Two important administrative acts were performed by the Executive Department to-day. The Secretary of the Treasury has finally decided that the 10,000,000 of silver dollars now in the vaults must go out. To accomplish this he has caused to be issued a circular, which provides that silver dollars may be obtained by any person in the same manner in which fractional silver currency can now be obtained.

Marshall, Democratic ex-Supervisor of the town of White Plains, and member for that town of the Democratic Committee of Westchester County, is again under arrest for alleged wrong-doing in an official capacity, and is lodged in White Plains Jail awaiting an examination which he, or rather his counsel, Chauncey Shaffer, has demanded. To the first annual regatta of the Police Department, rowed on the Harlem River yesterday afternoon, must be accorded the distinction of being the worst managed regatta of the season. It had been well advertised, and excited so much interest among the friends of the force that several thousand of them flocked to the Harlem to witness the rowing.

DEAR SIR: I have, as requested by you, examined the several nets of Congress relative to the District of Columbia 3.65 bonds, so called, and the opinions and other papers submitted|by you on that subject. These obligations are in form certificates of indebtedness of the District of Columbia.

BURLINGTON, Sept. 3. The State election to-day was generally quiet, with some close and exciting contests for the local offices. Returns from 60 towns indicate a majority of 17,000 or 18,000 for Proctor and the Republican State ticket, on a light vote.

Fortunately, our second "heated term" comes late in the season, and at almost any time during the present month we are liable to have a turn in the temperature which will bring us frosty nights. If New-York escapes the epidemic of yellow fever which is desolating the cities of the South-west, very little credit will be due to its Municipal authorities.

HARTFORD, Sept. 3. P. Jewell Sons started a subscription yesterday for the yellow fever sufferers with $100, and ex-Gov. Jewell took hold in person and made a canvass, and, with others whom be enlisted, has succeeded in raising, up to this afternoon, $1,000, which has been put in Mayor Sum ner's hands to be forwarded.
The William P. Dixon whose name appeared in the list of bankrupts is not the William P. Dixon, a lawyer, of No. 50 Wall-street.

A special meeting of the Medical Society of the County of New-York was held at the College of Physicians and Surgeons, Fourth-avenue and Twenty-third-street, last evening, "to provide ways and means for aiding the suffering physicians of the South-west and their families." The society has between 600 and 700 members, of whom 75 were present last evening.

ALBANY, Sept. 3. The State Board of Equalization met to-day in the office of the Secretary of State, to consider the equalization of assessments made by the Assessors throughout the State among the various counties. There were present Secretary of State Beach, who presided, Controller Olcott, Treasurer Mackin, Attorney-General Schoonmaker, and the three Assessors, those of the board absent being the Lieutenant-Governor, State Engineer, and Speaker of the Assembly.

President Babcock, of the Pacific Mail Steamship Company, yesterday morning confirmed Director Hart's denial of the report that that company had resolved to raise its rates on freight, beginning yesterday, to correspond with the recent enormons advance made by the Union and Central Pacific Railroad Companies.

The Republican General Committee of Kings County held its first meeting last evening since the Summer recess, Erastus Cook, the President, in the chair. At the last meeting of the committee in May, a resolution was adopted striking from the roll the names of all members who had not paid their yearly dues.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 3 12 P.M. A member of the Young Men's Christian Association returning from a visit to his patients at a late hour to-night reports the increase in the number of cases as fearful, attributing it to the continuous rain to-day.
Miss Josie Bailey will act at the Fifth-Avenue Theatre in the support of Modjeska. Mr. Bronson Howard wishes it to be understood that "Hurricanes" is not a "comedy," but simply a "comic drama."

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 3. Gen. B. F. Butler's much-advertised speech was delivered at the City Hall this evening, and for an opening of the campaign in Western Massachusetts it evidently lacked that enthusiasm which he had hoped for.

HARRISBURG, Sept. 3.--The Board of Pardons had under consideration this evening the case of Jack Kehoe, the Mollie Maguire, convicted as a participant in the killing of F. W. S. Langdon, at Audenried, Schuylkill County, in June, 1862. The case for Kehoe was argued by Anthony Campbell and J. W. Ryan.

The programm of Theodore Thomas concert last evening was an excellent specimen of that intelligant combination of representative popular and classical music to which the habitues of the Garden have become accustomed this season. Nearly all the sections were familiar ones.
The heat on Monday brought the consumption of water in this city on that day up to 35,800,000 gallons.

LONDON, Sept. 4. The excursion steamer Princess Alice, returning from Gravesend to London last evening, with about 700 passengers on board, was run down off Barking, about 8 o'clock, by a screw steamer, and many hundred lives lost, variously estimated at from 500 to 650. The highest estimate is the latest, and is given by the London Steam-boat Company, the owners of the Princess Alice.

Enough has been said by Mr. DENIS KEARNEY, in his various harangues throughout the country, to show us what sort of a government we should live under if the Kearneyites had their way. Of course, this mountebank has some following. Of the few thousands who go to hear him, a fair proportion is made up of men who are ready to accept all he says as gospel truth.

Alexander M. Lesley, late President of the defunct Trade Savings Bank, whose petition has been referred to Register Dwight, has liabilities amounting to $62,000, and no assets. There are two judgements against him for $21,516, obtained by the Receiver of the bank for mortgage deficiency and balance of account. The principal creditors are the estate of George Lesley, $28,777; G. Davis, $3,500; James H. Ingersoll, $1,000.

VICKSBURG, Sept. 3. There were 36 deaths to-day whites, 23; colored, 13. It is impossible to give figures as to the new cases. Only one physician found time to report to-day, and his account is 100 visits and 60 new cases.

WATER VALLEY, Miss., Sept. 3. Holly Springs reports 58 cases of some kind of fever to-day, which the physicians have not diagnosed. There have been four deaths there. It is, doubtless, yellow fever. The citizens are fleeing in every direction.

Detective Looney, of the Brooklyn Central Office, made an important arrest last evening at No. 130 Bergen street, in that city. The prisoner, who is a young, well-dressed man of good appearance, gave his name as Henry Hart. On Monday night, Superintendent Campbell received a dispatch from the Chief of Police of New-Bedford asking him to arrest Hart, who, under the name of Henry A. Howard, had stolen $1,000 worth of jewelry in New-Bedford.

Nearly all the members of the Board of Aldermen were present at their regular meeting yesterday. The first business transacted was the consideration of a report of the Law Committee in favor of ceding a triangular piece of land at the battery to the United States for the purpose of a barge office, the amount for the same to be fixed by the Sinking Fund Commissioners.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 3.--The mystery attending the movements in this city of young Anson Dodge and his cousin, Miss Ida Dodge, who eloped from Philadelphia on Sunday, is at last solved. The young couple arrived here early yesterday morning, and proceeded to the Ebbitt House, where they registered as A. M. Young and Miss Mary C. Young.

The Board of Directors of the National Rifle Association held its monthly meeting yesterday afternoon, Major-Gen. Shaler in the chair. The members present were Col. Bodine, Col. Gildersleeve, Col. Scott, Major Fulton, Capt. Story, Gen. Wylie, Gen. Wingate, D.W. Judd, and J.P. Waters.

MEMPHIS, Sept. 3. The atmosphere is heavy with the stench of dead bodies. Several corpses were found to-day, and no one was able to tell where or how they died. It is impossible to describe the condition of affairs here.

BOSTON, Sept. 3. The address of the Young Republicans, which the Executive Committee were instructed at the recent Worcester conference to prepare, will be published in the morning papers. It is a brief, vigorous, and clearly pointed document.

Henry Steele, father of Col. D.S. Steele and a well-known resident of Jersey City, died suddenly at his home on Sussex-street yesterday. Joseph Booth, a Director of the Essex County National Bank, a well-known business man of East Orange, died suddenly yesterday.

WATER VALLEY, Miss., Sept. 3. The situation at Grenada to-night is fearful. There was much distress and suffering last night, and to-day furnished six more bodies for interment and 12 now cases for treatment.
READING, Penn., Sept. 3 Hon. Hiester Clymer was this morning unanimously renominated for a fourth term in Congress by the Democratic County Convention.

HARRISBURG, Sept. 2 The Greenback Party of this city opened the campaign to-night by a mass-meeting, with their candidate, Hon. S.R. Mason, as the chief speaker. After a great deal of drumming and ringing of the Court-house bell, the meeting was opened, with the house only about half full.

HASTINGS, Minn., Sept. 9. President Hayes and party left St. Paul at 11:35 this morning, and arrived at Hastings at 1 o'clock. The space about the depot was densely packed with people. A large delegation of prominent men received the distinguished guests with bands playing and cannon firing.

Rev. H.L.E. Pratt, who was arrested a week ago in Central Park by Officer Burns, accused of a serious offense before Justice Bixby, and discharged after a hearing at 12 o'clock the night of his arrest, writes an answering statement to THE TIMES to protect his good name. He says that he has not before replied because he desired to address himself to the "sober second thought" of those who had wondered at his silence.

BERLIN, Sept. 9. The German Government recently sent a circular to the signatories of the Treaty of Berlin, asking them to take a common step with the view of bringing the Porte to execute the stipulations of the treaty. Austria, France, and Russia replied affirmatively. Italy and England have not yet answered, but will doubtless reply affirmatively soon.

MEMPHIS, Sept. 9. The condition of this city grows more desperate every hour. Of new cases it is useless longer to keep a count. Whole families are stricken down within a few hours, and the call for nurses is greater than can be supplied. Yesterday there were about 100 deaths and 300 new cases, and to-day, up to noon, 70 deaths had been reported.

Miss Cavendish has long occupied a leading position upon the English stage, and in London her abilities have ben generously recognized.

PORTLAND, Sept. 9. The worst fears of the friends of honest money in this State have been realized. From the returns now in and they are very full it is evident that the Greenbackers have cast from 33,000 to 40,000 votes, and that none of the candidates for Governor has received a majority of all the votes cast.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 9. From 12 M. to 10 P.M. there have been 36 deaths recorded, the largest number within that space of time during the season. The number of new cases is on the decrease, however, and gives hope that the climax has been reached. Your correspondent held a consultation with several eminent physicians to-day upon the subject.

The Swiss riflemen of the Helvetia Rifle Club had a pleasant day yesterday to begin their shooting at the Schuetzen Park, Union Hill, N.J. The attendance was small in the early part of the day, but the crowd increased considerably, so that when the dancing began in the evening the pavilion was well filled.

The United States Local Inspectors of Steam Vessels, Messrs. Jayne and Matthews, will shortly open an inquiry into the causes of the explosion which took place on board the excursion steamer Moses Taylor on Sunday last. The public, as no one knows better than Mr. Boucicault, cares little indeed whence comes the inspiration, so long as the result is strongly effected.

KEOKUK, Iowa, Sept. 10. Hon. George W. McCrary, Secretary of War, delivered an address on the " Political Issues of the Time," before a large assemblage, at his home, in this city, this evening. Loud applause greeted the telling passages, and there was every evidence of popular enthusiasm.

" Have you heard the news from Maine ?" is an inquiry which reappears with a significance as great as that which it possessed in the Harrison campaign. This time it is propounded by the Greenbackers. To them the news brings good cheer. It does not fulfill all their boasts, but it more than justifies the claim to consideration which politicians who cannot see beyond their noses have stubbornly refused to recognize.
The Missouri Greenbackers are to hold a three days' convention in St. Louis, beginning Oct. 1.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 10. There has been a peculiarity about the conventions of both parties in this State this Fall. The Republicans have been peculiarly harmonious, and have generally nominated their candidates by acclamation, while the Democrats have invariably wrangled and balloted almost endlessly, indulging in all manner of ill-feeling.

MADISON, Wis., Sept. 10. At Lake City last night, at midnight, the President addressed the assembled people, and went through the inevitable hand-shaking while the rest of his companions were buried in slumber or too drowsy to trouble themselves. Even the booming of cannon failed to awaken many of them, and certainly did not get them out of their comfortable berths.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 10.-Mr. George H. Pendleton delivered a long speech here tonight, which was mainly a plea for greenback inflation. He savagely attacked the national banking system. He denied that coin equal to one-quarter or one-third the amount promised by national bank-notes will suffice to keep them at par, and asserted that history does not support this assertion.

The Produce Exchange has received from the Canal Auditor a comparative tabulated statement showing the amount of business done on the canals during August and since the opening of navigation this year and last. The quantities are reduced to tons.

The rumored charges against the Register of this County have assumed shape, and will doubtless be presented to the Governor for action within a day or two. A number of signatures of prominent lawyers, who are personally aware of transgressions of law on the part of the accused official, have been appendeded to the petition which calls for the latter's removal.

BOSTON, Sept. 10. The result in Maine has stirred the leaders of both parties in this State to sudden activity, has cheered Butler amazingly, and has rendered the Greenbackers, who hold their State Convention in this city to-morrow, boisterously boastful. At Butler's head-quarters there were crowds of callers all day, and the General was beaming.
BOSTON, Sept. 10. Tuesday being the last day of the meeting of the Beacon Jockey Club, a large crowd was in attendance. The weather was good and the track in excellent condition.
VICKSBURG, Miss., Sept. 10. The weather here is clear and warm, the thermometer registering 89 . The indications are that the fever is decreasing as regards new cases, but the mortality is fearful.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Sept. 10. The second day of the races on the Kentucky Association course was delightful; not hot, with a hazy sky. The attendance was quite moderate less than yesterday. The racing was merely food. The first race was for 3-year olds that had never won; mile heats. It brought out 8 of 16 entries. Beechwood, Nellio Booker, Petrel, Signal, Grapple, Richards' colt by War Dance, Tom Barlow, and Reynolds' colt by Melbourne, Jr.

Prop. Graham read an essay last evening at Science Hall on the alleged brains of B.F. Butler and Denis Kearney, phrenologically considered. The Professor was flanked by a number of phrenological charts, presumably representing the two subjects under consideration. That representing Kearney looked like a map of the Eastern Hemisphere, with parallels of latitude and longitude, the portion occupied by China being in deepest black.

CONCORD, Sept. 10. The Republican State Convention met this forenoon, nominated Gen. Natt Head for Governor, and a Board of Railroad Commissioners, adopted a platform containing a strog hard-money plank and not especially outspoken on any other subject, and adjourned, the delegates generally feeling satisfied with their work.

Enthusiastic Butlerites are so far encouraged by the partial success of the Maine Greenbackers that they are ready to declare that the election of their champion in Massachusetts is now assured. It is certain that the danger of a Greenback triumph in Massachusetts is made more obvious, though it does not follow that it is one whit increased, by the result in Maine.

Holman, the former white and the latter colored. Both died at 8 o'clock this morning, Mrs. Martin at Barrow Hill Hospital and Holman at Fisk University.

There has never been an investigating committee so harmonious as that now in session in the New-York Custom-house. It consists of one man FERNANDO WOOD. For once, at least, there is no wrangling, no disputation, and no clashing. Hon. FERNANDO Wood agrees with himself. All investigating committees have agreed that the Customhouse ought to be investigated.

He began by congratulating the workers in the Greenback movement on the changes for the butter that have recently occurred to their party.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 14.--J. R. Weaver, Postmaster at Lake Station, Miss., reports to Surgeon-General Woodworth that the first case of yellow fever in that town occurred Aug. 31. Since then there have been 57 cases, 17 of which resulted fatally. Three new cases have developed within the last 24 hours.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 15.--To-morrow's death-roll will be deemed a criterion of the defervescence of the plague. There were 59 deaths for the 24 hours ending at noon to-day. Up to 6 o'clock to-night there were 20 deaths and 150 new cases reported.

BELGRADE, Sept. 15.--News comes from Bosnia that the Austrian reinforcements have commenced offensive operations against the insurgent intrenchments on the banks of the Save. When the soldiers encamped at Creedmoor turned out of bed at sunrise yesterday morning the weather prophets predicted "a shower before night." An inquest was begun in the Brooklyn Morgue last evening by Coroner Simms into the manner and causes of the collision that occurred on Saturday last at the Brooklyn-avenue crossing of the Atlantic-Avenue Division of the Long Island Railroad, and which resulted in the killing of three persons and the wounding of four others.

The Surrogate's Court was again crowded yesterday when the Vanderbilt will case was called, The parties to the suit and the full array of counsel were present. The proceedings included the disposal of the case of Mrs. Stoddard by the Surrogate refusing to commit her for alleged perjury.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 2. At Carrollton the total cases number 200; under treatment, 110. There were five deaths yesterday. Most of the sick are in destitute circumstances, and are supplied by the Seventh District Relief Association.

LONDON, Oct. 2. Various special dispatches agree in stating that negotiations are progressing at Vienna to prevent a change of the entire administration, and that the difficulty is increased by the growing dissatisfaction in Hungary with Count Andrassy's whole policy in connection with the Eastern question.

The case of Fitz John Porter was about closed on Tuesday, and yesterday, in the court-room on Governor's Island, Major Asa Bird Gardner, the Judge-Advocate, opened for the Government, presenting his argument in rebuttal. Gen. Schofield,...

The Trustees of the Peabody Education Fund held their annual meeting in the Fifth-Avenue Hotel yesterday morning, Hon. Robert C. Winthrop, of Massachusetts, President of the Board, occupying the chair.

The nominations made by the Hudson County Democrats, last Friday, for Congressman Sheriff, and Coroners, have given riss to the most general unconcealed dissatisfaction among the members of that party.

BOSTON, Oct. 2. On Monday afternoon Gov. Rice sent a most dignified and courteous, though at tho same time direct and caustic, reply to the angryletter of Gov. Wade Hampton, of South Carolina, on his refusal to surrender Kimpton to the South Carolina authorities; but he has not sanctioned its publication...

The Chamber of Commerce Relief Committee have issued a circular announcing that next week the City from Fourth-street to Central Park will be canvassed by sub-committees for clothing for the benefit of the yellow fever sufferers in the South.

A small crowd assembled at the Prospect Park Fair Grounds at Gravesend yesterday to witness three races which were announced to take place there, It was the first of a two-days meeting, to be conducted under the rules of the American Jockey Club so it was given out but there was nobody present to preserve order, and a more roisy crowd, in proportion to the numbers, was never gathered on a race-track.

The attempt which the officers of some forty or fifty fire insurance companies have for the past six months been making to reorganize the National Board of Underwriters, for the purpose of establishing a systematic tariff of rates, seems to have resulted in complete failure.
LONDON, Oct. 2. The liabilities of the City of Glasgow Bank, which closed its doors to-day, are stated at $50,000,000. The liability of the shareholders is unlimited.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 2. On the 25th of August last Robort Whitaker, possessed of $1,000,000, was killed on the Pennsylyania Railroad near Bristol, Penn., by a train from New-York to this city. Whitaker was a business man of Philadelphia, and resided here, having his country-seat near the place where he was killed.

HARTFORD, Oct. 2. Gen. Hawley is on the Algeria, not yot arrived in New-York, and as it is not known here whether he will accept the nomination as a candidate for Congress, the convention tomorrow may be embarrassed, as there is a strong feeling to have him run, and other candidates are depending upon his action.

The match at cricket between the 11 of Australia and 18 of New-York was continued from the previous day, yesterday morning, at the St. George's Grounds, Hoboken. More interest has bean displayed in this match than in any of a similar character played here.

A row of frame buildings fronting on Passaic-avenue, East Newark, was destroyed by fire early yesterday morning. The flames broke out either in the large building occupied by the Hyde Manufacturing Company, or in the boat-house and saloon of Freeman Bowers, adjoining, and spread with such rapidity that by the time Chief Banedict, of the Newark Fire Department, arrived with two...

MEMPHIS, Oct. 2. It rained heavily this morning at daylight, and the weather is now sultry and warm. The Howard Association today sent nurses to Rossville, Moscow, and Brownsville, Tenn., and Garner, Miss. Bishop...

LOWELL, Mass., Oct. 2. The Republican Convention in Butler's district, held in this city to-day, was not so lively as anticipated by the few who knew the character of the resolutions to be introduced against Butler, for the simple reason that not a single delegate appeared to oppose them.

BALLSTON SPA, Oct. 2. The prosecution in the case of the People against Jesse Billings, Jr., continued their effort to impeach some of the principal witnesses for the defense to-day, and succeeded in getting in a good deal of testimony of a nature damaging to the prisoner's case. Counsel for the defense fought the evidence hard all day, interposing an objection to every question and answer of any importance.

MEMPHIS, Oct. 3. Last night was quite cool, and indications of a light frost were seen this morning. A case of noble self-sacrifice is given in the death of Miss Carrie Rutter, who died early this morning.

The second day of the so-called runningmeeting at the Prospect Park Fair Grounds was better attended than the preceding one, but those who ventured to make the journey to the course did not conceal their disgust at the management.

The first meeting of the Chamber of Commerce since the Summer vacation was held yesterday, William H. Appleton and Sinclair Tousey were appointed delegates to represent the Chamber at the Postal Convention to be held in this City on Oct. 9.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 3. The international cricket match between the Australian eleven and Philadelphia eleven attracted an assemblage of about 5,000 persons to the beautiful ground at Germantown to-day, unusual interest being shown in this match, as it is the only one in America in which the Australians are met even-handed, all other games being against odds.

At Steinway Hall last evening Theodore Thomas gave his second and final farewell concert, prior to his departure for the West. According to previous announcements, this concert was tendered to the celebrated leader by "prominent citizens of New-York and Brooklyn;" and it was anticipated that his career as a musician in this City would, therefore, be closed in the most brilliant manner.

The Receivers of the suspended German Savings Bank of Morrisania, Mr. William J. Best, yesterday began to pay to the depositors a second dividend of 10 per cent., having previously paid one of 15 per cent. The bank was opened at 10 o'clock ...

TALBOT says truly, that "were it possible to surround ourselves with a wall of exclusion, we might, for our own exchange, have any standard we chose, but the spirit of the age, the universal interchange and communion of nations, renders such a thing impossible."

The Chamber of Commerce Relief Committee yesterday directed the following remittances to be made: To Port Gibson, through the Howard Association of New-Orleans, $500; to the Peabody Relief Association of New-Orleans, $1,500; to the Young Men's Christian Association of New-Orleans, $1,000; to the Howard Association of Vicksburg, for surrounding places, $1,000.

The recently-elected General Committee of the New-York County Democratic organization (Cooper-Ottendorfer wing of the Anti-Tammanyites) met last evening at Irving Hall and organized for the ensuing year.
NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 3.--Society was shocked to-day to hear of the death of Mr. and Mrs. James J. Irby. Both were buried together this afternoon.

The cavalry and artillery organizations of the Second Division, Brooklyn, and the Seventeenth Separate Company of Infantry, Flushing, went to Creedmoor yesterday for final rifle practice for the present season. Capt. H.M. Mohrman, of Troop ...

LOWVILLE, N.Y., Oct. 3. The Republican Congressional Convention of the Twenty-second District to-day nominated Hon. Warner Miller, of Herkimer, for Congress. Mr. Miller, in accepting the nomination, made a hard-money speech.

The examination in the case of Sarah Victoria Connors, of No. 307 East Twenty-sixth-street, who is supposed to have died from the effects of malpractice, took place yesterday before Justice Kilbreth, in the Tombs.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 3. Attorney-General Devens, in accordance with a request received from the Secretary of the Treasury, has directed District Attorney Woodford, at New-York, to examine the title to the land adjoining that now belonging to the United States, and next to the new Whitehall boat slip, upon which the new barge office in New-York City is to be located.

Mr. Wood's associates on the Sub-committee of the Committee on Ways and Means, appointed to investigate the Customs system, were consistent in remaining away to the end. Yesterday morning Mr. Wood placed Appraiser Dutcher upon the stand for the third time, and asked him whether there had been any changes in Assistant Appraisers during his terms of office.

A wild steer, which is supposed to have escaped from the cattle pens at Forty-fourth-street, East River, created a greet deal of excitement and consternation in the east side of the City yesterday afternoon, as he dashed through the crowded thoroughfares, chasing and being chased by crowds of men and boys.
Customs Inspector Edward Duffy seized yesterday, three hogsheads and one cask of smuggled wine on the bark F. Pirandallo, from Messina.

BOSTON, Oct. 3. To the consternation of his friends in the convention, and of himself, Gen. Banks was beaten in the Republican Convention in his district the Fifth held to-day in Charlestown, and the least formidable of his opponents carried off the prize.

Carl Koenig and his wife Bertha, natives of Bielfield, Germany, arrived in this City as second cabin passengers on the Steam-ship State of Virginia, on Friday, Sept. 27. They took lodgings at Foley's Hotel, No. 274 West street, Mr. Koenig had $400 gold in his possession.

NEW-ORLEANS, Oct. 3. A. Campbell, telegraph operator at Canton, Miss., died on Wednesday, and Clark Harvey, who went from Brook Haven to take the place of a sick operator at Tangipahoa, died there last night. G.T. Raroul, operator at Osyka, is very low. F.W. Gustine, operator, of this city, was taken with fever last night. All are doing well here except Capt. Fitzsiminons, whose condition is considered critical.
The inquest in the case of the unknown woman whose body was found at Silver Lake, Staten Island, was resumed on Wednesday evening by Coroner James Dempsey, at Librarp Hall, NewBrighton.

BALLSTON SPA, Oct. 3. So far as the taking of testimony is concerned, the trial of Jesse Billings, Jr., has ended. The rebutting testimony for the People was closed at noon to-day, and after occupying the afternoon in the introduction of testimony in rebuttal, counsel for the prisoner rested their case to-night.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 3. Lieut. H.H. Benner, Eighteenth Infantry, and Lieut. Charles S. Hall, Thirteenth Infantry, who are to have charge of the expedition for tha relief of the yellow fever sufferers along the banks of the Mississippi River between Memphis and Vicksburg, arrived here last night.

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 3. To many not acquainted with the circumstances attending the trial of Rev. Herbert H. Hayden for the murder of Mary E. Stannard, in Madison, his prompt discharge seemed inexplicable, because of the peculiar evidence which had been announced as in existence against him.

The defense in the Fitz John Porter case yesterday morning unmasked what was supposed to be a battery, in an attempt to discredit the testimony of Capt. Douglas Pope relative to the famous 4:30 P. M. order, transmitted to Gen. Porter on the critical afternoon of Aug. 29, 1862.

Prof. NEWCOMB, in his late address to his scientific brethren at the meeting of their association at St. Louis, took up what the Germans would call one of "the burning questions" of the day the relations of scientific investigation to theism and to the doctrine of final causes.

A shocking sight was witnessed on board the steam-ship City of Chester, of the Inman Line, last evening. The ship reached her pier at the foot of Chariton-street yesterday morning, on her arrival from Liverpool, and in the afternoon was put into the hands of the stevedores for the purpose of unloading.
One of the worst bank failures of this generation has taken place in a country renowned for the prudence and skill of its banks.

BALLSTON SPA, Oct. 4. An hour before the court opened this morning, an immense crowd of men and womon had gathered in front of the closed doors, blocking up the verands and stops, and extending through the courtyard into the street. The special friends of the numerous attaches of the court went early to the private entrance, and were allowed to enter.
NEW-ORLEANS, La., Oct. 4. A.W. Dennett, telegraph operator at Vicksburg, and L.M. Pennington, telegraph train dispatcher at Water Valley, died this morning of yellow fever.

Detectives Taylor and Arnold arrived in this City about 11 P.M. on Thursday, and went to Police Head-quarters at Stapleton, Staten Island, yesterday morning.
The second concert of the Roze-Mapleson company was given last night at Steinway Hall. A numerous audience was present, and the efforts of the various artists won frequent and hearty applause.

OGALLALA, Neb., Oct. 4. The Cheyennes crossed the railroad at an uninhabited point in the open country, five miles east of here, at 11 o'clock this morning, and proceeded due north. Ten mounted scouts followed to observe their movements, and overtook a small party of Indians ...

The Fall meeting of the American Jockey Club, which will open to-day, promises to be very brilliant, and an additional race each day to the four on the regular programme, which it is proposed to give, will afford ample sport.
POUGHKEEPSIE, Oct. 4 Reports from points south of this city give the particulars of a severe earthquake shock along both sides of the Hudson from Marlborough to Peekskill, a distance of 25 miles.

LONDON, Oct. 4. The Manchester Guardian's Vienna dispatch says: "The political crisis is becoming more serious. The members of the two Cabinets will only consent to retain their portfolios on condition that Count Andrassy retires. The Austrian Cabinet considers his financial demands inadmissible."

LIVERPOOL, Oct. 4. This week's circular of the Liverpool Cotton Brokers' Association says: "Cotton, early in the week, was firm, and considerable business was done. Prices for some descriptions were higher. Since Tuesday the market has been quiet, and a part of the advance has been lost. American is in good demand.

NEW-HAVEN, Oct. 4. Two horses were driven rapidly up to the jail in this city just before noon today, and in the carriage behind them was the worst scared man in the State, and he had excellent cause.

Capt. Gastlin, of the Western Steam-boat Squad, last evening arrested two dangerous confidence operators and locked them up at Police Headquarters. About 5 o'clock the Captain went aboard the steamer Drew, as she was preparing to leave on her evening trip to Albany.

LONDON, Oct. 4 The total of the liabilities of Messrs. Smith, Fleming Co., East India merchants. London, whose failure was announced yesterday, is estimated at over $10,000,000. The liabilities of their corresponding firms which fail with them William Nicol Co., of Bombay, and Fleming Co., of Kurrachee are, doubtless, considerably less.

COLUMBUS, Oct. 5.--This has been a sad day for the Democracy, and John G. Thompson has been cast down by the gloom which surrounds him.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Oct. 5.--Dr. Vandeman, Registrar, reports that for the 24 hours ending 4 P.M., there were two deaths from yellow fever, both colored, and 21 new cases, 14 of whom are colored.

BALLSTON SPA, Oct. 5.--Another very large audience gathered at the Court-house this morning, but Judge Landon's instructions to prevent a crush were better obeyed to-day than yesterday, and only as many people were allowed in the room as would fill it without unnecessary discomfort. While the clerk was calling the jury, Jesse Billings came in with the Sheriff, twirling a nosegay in his fingers, and nodding and smiling to his counsel and friends.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 5.--In the recent discussions of the Treasury Department upon the construction to be given to acts of Congress relating to the tariff and navigation, are the following: Spanish printed glazed tiles, generally used in wainscottings, mantel, grate, and stove fronts, must pay a duty of 40 per cent. ad valorem, the same as paving tiles.

PATERSON, Oct. 5.--A fire was discovered at 10:40 o'clock to-night in the Passaic Rolling Mills, in South Paterson, adjoining the Erie Railway buildings. The mill was a cheap frame structure, but very extensive, covering three or four acres. One story was filled with machinery of the costliest and most improved description.

The County Convention of the Blair-Connolly wing of the Greenback-Labor Party assembled last evening in the Germania Assembly Rooms, George Blair in the chair, and Dr. E.B. Foote acting as Secretary.

KINGSTON, Sept. 26.--The island has been in a painful state of suspense for the past few days, owing to its being known that a hurricane in the Caribbean Sea is now steadily making its way in a north-westerly direction and calculated at its present velocity to strike Jamaica on the 27th and the southern coast of Cuba on the 28th.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 5.--The cricket game was resumed at 11:40 o'clock this morning, with the Philadelphians at the bat. The weather was fine and the attendance large. The interest felt, however, was hardly so intense as yesterday, it being an almost foregone conclusion that the game would be drawn, as it scarcely seemed possible for the two innings to be played out in the one day.

A remarkable case of alleged abandonment was before Justice Morgan, in the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday afternoon. Mrs. Amelia Lindo, of No. 25 Abingdon-square, had her husband, Gabriel Lindo, arrested for deserting her, as he was about to take a steamer for Jacksonville, Fla. Mrs. Lindo, who is a very handsome woman, said her husband is a rich man, having $10,000 in jewelry alone among his personal property.

The American Jockey Club were favored with a perfect day for the opening of their Autumn meeting. The clear blue of the sky was unmarred by a fleck of cloud.

VIENNA, Oct. 5.--An official report from Gen. Philippovich says a large majority of Bosnians, including Mohammedans, welcome the crushing of the insurrection, with unquestionably sincere assurances of devotion and loyalty to the Austrian Crown.

NORTH PLATTE, Neb., Oct. 5.--A mail carrier who arrived here this evening from Norton, Kan., via Indianola, Neb., says that 17 men are known to have been killed by Indians in the vicinity of Sappa. He says the hostiles were raiding Beaver Creek on Wednesday. All is quiet at Indianola, though the people between there and Platte Valley are much excited.

More delightful weather for all the purposes of an election could not have been desired than the people of Connecticut have had at their annual town meetings to-day, and yet the vote generally has been light, except in a few towns where, for local reasons, some excitement has prevailed, and the voters have gone to the polls.

COLUMBUS, Oct. 7. If Hon. Lorenzo English, the Independent candidate for Congress in this district, is not elected over Converse, the Democratic nominee, it can't be charged to lukewarmness on the part of the Republicans and a large number of Democrats who have been working night and day for the past month in his interest.

NEWTON, N.J., Oct. 7. The largest Republican County Convention held in many years took place to-day, and was solid for hard money. The following ticket was nominated: For Assembly, Capt. Daniel Bailey; for Surrogate, John W. Lane; for Sheriff, J.B. Hendershot.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 7. The receipts of national bank notes for redemption to-day were over $300,000. Treasury officials now consider it doubtful whether the recent order of Secretary Sherman requiring senders of such notes to pay the express charges on them will result in as great a decrease of redemption as was at first predicted.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 7. The following was receiced here from Pittsburg to-day: The Deputy Attorney-General has asked leave on behalf of the State to file in the Supreme Court separate bills asking for injunctions against the United Pipe Lines, the Atlantic and Great Western Railroad, the Dunkirk Railroad, the Allegheny Valley Railroad, the Pittsburg, Titusville and Buffalo Railroad, and the Pennsylvania Railroad Companies.

BALLSTON SPA, Oct. 7. The last word for Jesse Billings, Jr., on trial for the murder of his wife, was spoken by Gen. Hughes at 12 o'clock today, after a plea to the jury lasting two days and a half. As usual on Mondays, the court-room was not uncomfortably crowded this morning, and the General resumed his summing up with fewer hearers than on Friday and Saturday.

GRAFTON, West Va., Oct. 8. Returns from the Second Congressional District are meagre. However, Martin, Democrat is undoubtedly elected over Burr, Republican, and Thompson, Greenbacker. No definite figures will be available for several days.

BISMARCK, Dakota Territory, Oct. 8. The Indian excitement has reached here. The Seventh Cavalry, under Major Tilford, is in the field east of the Hills. CINCINNATI, Oct. 9. There is great rejoicing in Ohio to-day over the result of yesterday's election. It was a square hand-to-hand contest for honest money, with no compromises, dodges, or apologies, and the decision is so emphatic that no one can doubt its meaning.

Twenty men escaped from the jail in this city this (Saturday) noon, shortly before 1 o'clock. Their escape was effected by cutting through the wall. The plan of escape was evidently concocted several days ago, and perhaps weeks, but has been successfully concealed from the authorities, and carried out with great ingenuity. Numerous attempts have been made before by cutting through the wall, but never before have they met with success.

GLASGOW, Oct. 15. There is a panic in the iron trade here in consequence of a reported heavy failure and rumors of other suspensions. The prices of pig-iron were at one time 10 pence per ton lower on the day.

James De Koven delivered an address upon the "New Testament Doctrine of Absolution," which he declared could be summed up in the Bible statement, "Whosesoever sins ye remit, they are remitted unto them; whosesoever sins ye remit, they are retained."

COLUMBUS, S.C., Monday, Oct. 14, 1878. The inquiring traveler who comes to South Carolina hoping to find the people engaged in independent movements and the discussion of new and non-sectional issues will be disappointed. There are no Independents in this State. There are no new issues. The last-ditch Bourbons are still in command.

WASHINGTON, Oct. 18. An order has been issued by the War Department evacuating Fort Foote as a military post and signal service station. The company of troops and supplies now at the fort will be removed to the Washington Arsenal. Fort Foote is an earthwork erected during the war on the Maryland side of the Potomac, about eight miles below this city.

LONDON, Oct. 18. The Berlin correspondent of the Times reports that the native armies forming in Bulgaria and East Roumelia are under Russian officers, aquipped with Russian arms, commanded in the Russian tongue, and number about 50,000 men. Forcible enlistments continue. Arms are distributed by the Russians among the Christian villagers in East Roumelia, while the Turks provide rifles and ammunition for the Pomaks in the Rhodope Hills.

At the trial of the indicted officials of the People's Savings Bank of Newark, yesterday, Mr. Coult concluded his summing up in behalf of the defendants. He reviewed the testimony, and claimed that the evidence showed that the money loaned upon the notes held by the bank was good, and that the transactions were not irregular, as they were not made in violation of the chartered rights of the institution.

CAPE TOWN, Oct. 1, by way of Madeira, Oct. 18. The American ship Calcutta, Capt. Hansen, from Rangoon May 11, for the English Channel, has been towed in here by the American schoonet Gerogetta Lawrence, Capt. Coman with her rudder gone. The Georgetta Lawrence claims $50,000 salvage.

LONDON, Oct. 18. This morning's Financier says; "Although an increase in the Bank of England rate of discount to 7 per cent, would have been received calmly by the public, the absence of such action is hailed with satisfaction, as an indication that the Directors are content with the manner in which the crisis is being worked through, and see an improvement close ahead."

TROY, Oct. 16.--W.A. Wood is the Democratic candidate for Congress in this district, which comprises Rensselaer and Washington Counties. W. A. Wood is also the candidate of the Republicans for the same office. They are brothers, and both are manufacturers of reaping and mowing machines.

LONDON, Oct. 20.--Sir Stafford Northcote, speaking at Birmingham last night, admitted the depression in trade and consequent loss of elasticity of the revenue. Nevertheless, he did not anticipate the necessity of asking of the country renewed sacrifices. He condemned over-anxiety respecting the fulfillment of the provisions of the treaty of Berlin.
